column2: The Pancasila faith is a relatively new addition to the island of Borneo. Claiming to follow the teachings of their grand antediluvian leader Sukarno and acting more as a set of philosophical and political beliefs rather than a religion, its adherents believe themselves to be the true continuation of the Old World state of Indonesia. All Pancasila rulers consider themselves mere governors in a great Indonesia, regardless if they act independently or not. Those who believe in Pancasila claim that yang Maha Esa gave Sukarno the Five Principles and Thirty-Seven Commandments so that he could lead the people of Indonesia against the forces of wickedness who enslaved the people of Indonesia during his time and lead Indonesia into an age of peace and unity, which they could once again bring if they follow the Principles and Laws. Its followers are very tolerant of any monotheistic religion, seeing them as yet another aspect of yang Maha Esa and are quite charitable to the commoners as the Fifth Principle demands social justice for all Indonesians.
The Five Principles and Thirty-Seven Commandments

The Ahmadiyya are an Islamic messianic movement founded by Ahmad, who claimed to be the divinely appointed Promised Mahdi, revealing himself to the Muslims of India and promising to peacefully guide Islam to triumph. His goals were to restore Islam to their long-forgotten ways of peace and sympathy. The Ahmadiyya, his followers, at his word gave up the sword, and vowed to spread the true faith through peace and dialogue. Ahmad was succeeded by the Ahmadiyya Caliphs, who guided his followers and spread the faith around the world. Now, the Ahmadiyya stranded in the New World haven't given up their faith, nor their pacifist ways, and they hope to one day restore the true Caliphate and spread the word of Ahmad to all corners of the world, just as their Mahdi instructed.

Sarnaism is a folk religion practised primarily by the Kurukh and Munda peoples and spread throughout the Chota Nagpur plateau in eastern India. Claiming to be an ancient belief system existing since time immemorial, Sarnaism, known locally as Sarna Dhorom and to outsiders as the Religion of the Holy Woods, is a nature worshipping pagan faith largely detached from surrounding Hindu and Abrahamic religions. Though syncretism is commonplace, Sarnaists reject the Varna system and ignore any foreign religious texts, instead turning inwards, focusing on protecting and nurturing the nature around them. Having a vast and inconsistent amount of deities and spirits, the most frequently worshipped supreme creator is the Sun, known as Dharmes, a force of unquestionable good. The sacred Sarna grove is of especial importance, and it is believed the groves are the abode of Chala Pachchho, a powerful female deity commonly identified as a mother goddess of earth and nature. Once a year Sarnaists observe the Sarhul festival, a three day period of celebration in which adherents celebrate marriage between the Earth and the Sun and offer sacrifices to village deities.

Sarnaism is the folk religion of the Kurukh and Munda peoples of the Chota Nagpur plateau in eastern India. Claiming to be an ancient belief system existing since time immemorial, Sarnaism, known locally as Sarna Dhorom and to outsiders as the Religion of the Holy Woods, is a nature worshipping faith largely detached from surrounding Hindu and Abrahamic religions. Sarnaists reject the Varna system and foreign religious texts, instead following a codified set of deities and rituals. The supreme deity of the Sarna religion is the Sun god Dharmes, who is believed to be the force of unquestionable good in the world, hampered only by human vices. Sarnaists believe that the Old World was struck down by Dharmes as punishment for mankind's destruction of nature, and consider it their main duty to preserve and protect nature from those who wish to exploit and destroy it. Once a year Sarnaists observe the Sarhul festival, a three day period of celebration in which priests called Pahan offer sacrifices to the mother goddess Chala Pachchho and ancestral spirits, celebrating marriage between the Earth and the Sun.

Islam in China goes by many names - "Orthodox religion", "Cubic religion" or simply "Hui religion", but one word that is used by its followers to exemplify its virtues is "Qingzhenjiao", or the "Pure and True Religion". Due to its isolation from the wider ummah by successive Chinese governments, the Muslims of China have adopted peculiar practices influenced by the local Confucian and Daoist philosophies and other new Chinese religious traditions, such as ancestor veneration and a generally Confucian social outlook. In fact, many Muslims in China consider Confucius on par with the Prophet Muhammad, dubbing him the "Sage of the East" as opposed to the Prophet's status as the "Sage of the West". They will often translate Islamic concepts using Confucian terminology, culminating in the near-syncreticism of Confucianism and Islam present in many of their religious works, such as the Han Kitab, or the use of Taoist clothes by certain members of their Sufi orders.

Ak Jang is an indigenous religion that flourished among the Altai people of Russia's Altai Republic during the 1900s. The Russian Empire was suspicious of the movement's potential to stir up native unrest and perhaps involve outside powers and thus suppressed it. The religion was originally millenarian, charismatic and anti shamanic, the movement gradually lost most of these qualities becoming increasingly routine, institutionalized and accommodating itself to the pre existing Altaian folk religion. It is derived from a combination of Tengriism, Buddhism and Khurmaztism.

The fires of the Event freed the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints from the shackles of the quickly collapsing United States of America. The Church used this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to seize control of the former state of Utah, turning it into the newly-established Kingdom of Deseret. Tensions quickly began to rise, however, between the Church and the more fundamentalist groups of Mormon society, with many under the President demanding a return to the old ways, repealing various reforms passed after the Presidency of Joseph Smith, such as the abolition of polygamy and theodemocracy. The Church did not budge, and tensions finally boiled over in the year 2133, when the newly-proclaimed Brighamites rioted in Temple Square, causing a standoff that ended with its destruction and the excommunication of all who dare call themselves Brighamite.

Wishing for a return to what they consider the true Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints, the fundamentalist elements of Mormon society after the Event united under the name of Brigham Young, whom they consider the last true President. The Brighamites reject many of the newer reforms of the LDS Church, allowing men to marry multiple women, as well as reinforcing the political aspects of theodemocracy, which they consider instrumental in building up the Kingdom of God, something the mainstream Church believes refers to spiritual matters such as proselytisation. Unable to cause any permanent change in the Church, a large Brighamite mob in 2133 rioted in Temple Square, destroying the complex and getting excommunicated as a result. In the years since, those who still call themselves Brighamite were forced out of Salt Lake City and into the outskirts of Deseret and Mormon society as a whole, though the Brighamites have never stopped wishing for a Zion free from liberal reforms.

The trauma of the Event was ruthless to the Church, stranded far away from their Pope. The few surviving Catholic communities of the Pacific Northwest soon got overtaken by those wishing to prevent the wayward masses from turning to paganism, as many around them have done. Thus started the inquisition against folk saints and anything perceived as heresy. Very soon, these revivalist Catholics started exclusively celebrating the Tridentine Mass, and many started considering Latin a holy language, one in which the Holy Spirit speaks through the faithful. The most zealous of them started conversing exclusively in Latin, and in a short timeframe entire communities had abandoned their mother languages in place of one that had before been considered dead for millennia. Now, the believers in "Omniaveritatis", or the "All-Truthers" to those who do not speak their alien language, believe that the Last Pope ascended to Heaven during the Event, so he may return on Judgement Day to lead his faithful to battle against heathens alongside Jesus Christ himself. As such, they have become very militant in their beliefs, considering those around them to be barbaric heathens.

The Doukhobors or "spirit-fighters" are the pacifistic Spiritual Christians of the forested hinterlands of Beecy. Supposedly the descendants of ancient Russians who fled to the New World long before the Event, their religion is one of divine revelation on the individual level, believing that more important than any scripture or priestly guidance is personal contact with God. Their belief is that God dwells in every human being, and so rather than reading the Bible they pass down hymns and psalms orally, in a practice they call "the Living Book". Doukhobor society is generally communal, believing that every man is equal as all have God within them.

The Indian Shaker Church traces its heritage long before the Event. According to tradition, the Squaxin holy man Squ-sacht-un, also known as John Slocum, was killed in a logging accident on Skookum Inlet. During his wake, he sprung back to life, claiming that God had sent him to deliver a message to the Indian people - to stop smoking, drinking, and gambling, and instead seek Jesus. At the site of his resurrection, his newfound followers erected the first Indian Shaker church. The religion gets its name from the vigorous shaking its adherents do during prayer, believing it to be a source of healing powers. Indian Shakers believe that John Slocum was saved from a serious illness by his wife Mary, who had received the power of Jesus to cure disease as she began to shake, and she shook her body over John until he miraculously healed. Indian Shakers also do not read the Bible, instead believing in the power of gospel and direct revelations from God. Their churches are humble and plain, adorned with many handbells and crosses, though they seldom observe classic sacraments, their services instead consisting of bell-ringing, praying, and loud stomping.

The Numic people have lived in the Great Basin for millenia, and they still hold fast to the traditions of their ancestors. Puha or spiritual power is an element that runs throughout Numic religion, in things including rocks, animals, humans, or even the gods themselves. The religion is maintained orally by shamans, who conduct rituals and ceremonies for their tribes. The creation myth of the Numic religion speaks of Ocean Woman who birthed an island for humans to live and a time when animals were people.

The Seven Drums Religion, or the wáashat, is the traditional religion of the natives of the inland Northwest. Founded long before the Event by the Wanapum prophet Smohalla, who had died while travelling the Americas and was brought back to life by God. He led a return to the old ways of life of his people, reintroducing ceremonial music and dancing. His followers, the Dreamers, respect and follow the ways of their ancestors as well as the weyekin, the spirits of the land. They hold that God created people and Mother Earth, who gives the people plants and animals for food, so the Dreamers demand respect for the Earth they live on, refusing to buy or sell land as if it were a commodity. The prophets of the Dreamers commune with the spirit world through prophetic dreams, which are brought on by the signature Spirit Dance, through the playing of drums, ringing of brass bells, and ecstatic dancing.

The Scholastic Universalists are a deistic religion that developed out of the many university towns of the East Coast. Though it doesn't have a single orthodox creed, its adherents are unified in a single goal - a search for God by means of rationale, philosophy, and observation. The greatest Scholastics spend many years studying, researching faiths both familiar and exotic, and travelling far and wide in search of spiritual growth and answers many would consider unanswerable. The questioning of faith itself is heavily encouraged, and very little authority or hierarchy can be found among Scholastic Universalism, save for the Council of Deans, which organises and directs different universities in search for Old World knowledge.\nThus, in many ways, Scholastic Universalism resembles a grandiose research project more than it does a religion - temples are replaced by universities and libraries, time spent praying is instead spent with nose in books, and pilgrimage sites are decided on a personal level. These Scholastics have slowly but surely amassed what is considered the greatest collection of knowledge since the Event, one that is still slowly but surely growing in an endless search to understand God through any means necessary, be it through esoterica or through research and observation.

Myriadic Witchcraft worships no gods, and no masters. Though the followers of this school of witchcraft do not question nor deny the existence of gods, many worshipping different deities as they please, they also do not believe the gods of this world have any major influence on it. Rather, Myriadic witches draw their power and magick from Logos, the Word (and thus, the Will) of the universe. Logos manifests on Earth in many different forms, such as through the study of Qabalah, the proper application of astrology, or through elaborate and difficult to deciper manuscripts. Myriadic witches particularly enjoy studying chaos magick, and believe the more a person focuses on their belief in magick and the world around them, rather than worshipping gods, the more powerful their magick becomes. Myriadic witches also have a particular disregard for authority in all forms, believing organised religion to be the bane that wipes out all belief in magick wherever it goes.

The Students of the Illustrious Path are worshippers of the one supreme God, who transcends the universe. Though known by many names - Shangdi, Ishvara, Waheguru - God is absolute. The Illustrious Path and its Students are named for their belief in maya, the illusion of reality, a formless veil separating the human soul from oneness and conscious knowledge of the Absolute. They believe the absolute self and God are one and the same, though separated by bad karma and ignorance. Thus, his Students embark on the Illustrious Path, a lifelong path of learning and love in order to escape the eternal cycle of life and death and reunite with God in the Realm of Truth. Because God is formless and beyond human comprehension, his Students' love and devotion are directed towards the emanations of God that exist in the Court of the Lord, the primary one being the Illustrious Triune, who is the purest manifestation of God. The Illustrious Triune is the source of life and has three distinct aspects - the Heavenly Father, the Heavenly Mother, and the Honourable Guru. The Father rules the Celestial Bureaucracy and all the souls liberated from moksha, the Mother rules and is one with the Earth, and the Guru reincarnates in the mortal world to guide mortals on the Illustrious Path. Many historical figures are identified as the Guru by the Students, such as Laozi, Buddha, Jesus, and Guru Nanak, though they believe the next cycle of gurus is not to begin until the end of Kali Yuga.

Dianic Witchcraft focuses on the worship of the Goddess, a single great female deity whom they consider the creator of all life, as well as the primordial form of many different goddesses throughout many traditions and religions. The Great Goddess is one with the world - her divine energy flows through every living creature, and the whole Earth is simultaneously a piece of the Great Goddess.\nThe manifestations of the Goddess come in many different forms, but the most widely worshipped is that of the Triple Goddess - a divine trinity composed of the Maiden, associated with youth, the Mother, associated with the birth of life, and the Crone, associated with wisdom. Those who worship the Triple Goddess consider her to be an archetype that is personified through many different names and representations throughout history. The most common goddesses worshipped are Diana, associated with the Maiden, Gaia, associated with the Mother, and Hecate, associated with the Crone. Other less worshipped but nonetheless present deities include Selene, who is the personification of the Moon, and Persephone, the Queen of the Underworld.\nThe worshippers of the Goddess do not worship any male gods, believing that the pre-Event world was struck down by the Great Goddess as a result of her neglect. Dianic witches prefer to gather and worship in nature, which they consider a sacred gift from Mother Gaia. They are no strangers to casting spells and rituals to receive boons from their goddesses, though cursing others is generally looked down upon.

The Templarists take their name from an ancient order of Christian knights, rumoured to have been destroyed by the enemies of God centuries ago, its last leaders ascending to Heaven to fight in the Lord's army. Calling themselves protectors and loyal knights of old America, the Dominionists of the post-Event world quickly came to realise that soon there will be no America left to turn into the Kingdom of God. The prevailing belief became that it is upon the return of the Lord Jesus Christ that the true America will be rebuilt, ruled by the faithful under Biblical law. However, in order for Christ to return, he must be called upon by sacrifice, and reborn into a new mortal shell. Thus, the Templarists vow to call the Lord back to Earth by spilling the blood of infidels, the very same blood that Jesus will use to be reborn. The infidels that are killed are quickly baptised in order to cleanse their body and soul, so their blood may be pure enough for Jesus and the soul may ascend to Heaven's gates instead of suffering eternal torment. These loyal knights of America have vowed to never end their mission until their Lord returns and takes them into Heaven.

Dominion theology believes that America is a Christian nation, ruled by God's children and God's laws. However, the Dominionists of the post-Event world have found themselves in endless conflict with their Templarist brothers, who believe that America will be restored by Jesus Christ upon his return, and have taken it upon themselves to advance his return through the spilling of oceans of blood. The Dominionists find this belief appalling, instead insisting that it is the duty of every man who calls himself Christian to restore America, for Jesus will not return as long as America lies in ruin and paganism. Nonetheless, they are still divided on the many questions of Dominion theology, and stand far from united against the Templarist heresy.

Arcadian Witchcraft worships the Horned God, an omnipresent deity that represents the divine masculine of the universe. They believe that the Horned God personifies himself as many different gods throughout history, though every god can be traced back to an interpretation of the Horned God's divine will. The Arcadians most faithfully worship Pan, the satyr god of nature, mountains, the wilderness, as well as dryads and shepherds. They believe that Pan created the Earth in the form of a utopia called Arcadia, where every man was free to do as he wills, a world full of frolic and merriment. However, the greed and ambition of man led to the creation of giant states of decay and machines of destruction, and Arcadia was ultimately burned down in the Event. Now, the Arcadians are staunch protectors of what they believe to be the last scraps of a lost utopia - the Pacific Northwest. They believe that all of nature - from the rocks to the trees and the wildlife - contains divine spirits bestowed to it by the Horned God. Bustling woods, towering mountains, and endless wildlife, the Arcadians are the ones who keep careful watch for wildfires and those seeking to do nature harm, believing it is their duty to appease the spirits of nature and keep the mankind in harmony with the remnants of Arcadia.

Agama Tirta is a Hindu faith practised primarily by the people of the island of Bali. Believed to be the religion of Bali since time immemorial, folk legends claim it is the ancestral faith of all Nusantara, having already been reduced to obscurity before the Event. Formally monotheistic, Balinese worship is focused primarily on a supreme being called Acintya, also known as Sang Hyang Tunggai or Sang Hyang Widi Wasa. Worship of the Trimurti is commonplace, whom they consider to be manifestations of Acintya, occasionally identified as Shiva or Siwa-Sadasiwa-Paramasiwa. Deities not found in Indian Hinduism are also present. Bali Hindus still adhere to the varna system.
Emerged from the mixing between the Hellenic and Sea Creed religions, Poseidonians hold the belief that Poseidon, god of the seas, is the rightful heir to the Olympian pantheon.

The predecessor to later Jacobinism in postdeluvian Europe, the Girondists are a deistic faith which believes that the many gods of Europe are merely individual facets of a singular greater God. They believe that man was created in the image of God mentally and spiritually, but not physically. Monarchs are those chosen by god before birth to rule, however should a monarch fail in his duties as a king, or worse, become a tyrant, the third estate is obligated to either dethrone him or, if they are a tyrant, feed him to Madame Guillotine. The three Archangels of the Creator are Liberty, Equality, and Fraternity who intercede on the behalf of the Creator, helping the peasantry and telling them when a ruler has lost his divine right to rule. The religion was once fairly widespread in France, however in the centuries since it has seen assimilation of Novelist gods into its pantheon. Unlike its more aggressive Jacobinist descendant present in secret academic societies, it is relatively peaceful, hence its ability to assimilate into Novelist society.

Kalikula, meaning "Family of Kali" is the name for the Shaktist tradition of Kali worship most prevalent in northeastern India. Worship is focused on the goddess Kali as the main and most important manifestation of Brahman. Influenced by the teachings of the pre-Event guru Ramakrishna, modern Kali worship largely emphasises devotion (bhakti) over ritual, and as a result brahmin influence has greatly dropped after the Event. Other than Kali, worshipped deities include the Mahavidyas, Kaumari, Chandi, Durga, and many more regional gods and goddesses. Kali as the Supreme Being is considered both the loving mother of her children and their fierce guardian, and by extent the destroyer of evil. Worship is most often communal and carried out through festivals such as Kali Puja.

Arcenciste, colloquially called Jeannism is a heathen offshoot of Catholicism that has a cult-like following of Jeanne d'Arc, "the Maid of Orleans" amongst other saints, it was once much more common across France but has since been largely subsumed by Novelism. Jeanne led France to victory against the Queen's worshippers long before the Event in the fabled Siege of Orleans. According to legend, she was given the sword Joyeuse by Marianne, the guardian angel of France, which she used to smite the Queen's worshippers at Orleans. Vengeful, the followers of the Queen made a pact with the Devil, deceiving the Pope into branding Jeanne as a witch for which she was murdered. Though since canonised as a Saint, her loyal followers have not forgotten about this trickery and swear revenge against the wicked Queen and her worshippers, who have once again invaded their precious homeland, and therefore the Arcencists promise to cleanse France in the name of the Maid of God once more. Opinions on this religion vary, with both Catholics and Sevillians considering them heathen pseudo-pagans yet cautiously supportive of their crusade, while all those who worship the Queen are engaged in permanent hostility with the Arcenciste faithful. The religion has seen a resurgence under the Thelemite ruled regions of France.

Deha Tatta, meaning "truth in the body", is the name of the central theme and purpose of the songs of the Bauls. Bauls are the mystic troubadours of eastern India, who perform enigmatic songs and spread a message of love. Their music and poetry, called Baul sangeet, preaches about finding relationship with God and achieving spiritual liberation, seeking divinity within each person. They believe one should always be searching for Moner Manush - the "Man of their Heart", or the divine spirit of God manifested inside the body. Followers of Deha Tatta are as such devoted to Sadhana, the spiritual practice of transcending material things through purified love and devotion. The Bauls themselves come from various backgrounds, both from within the religion and from neighbouring religions like Islam and Hinduism. This act of coming together to preach love and mysticism has resulted in a unique blend of religions that has taken over Bengal since the Event.

Raëlism traces its roots back to the mythical pre-Event prophet known as Raël. The religion teaches that humanity was designed and created by an extraterrestrial race known as the Elohim. This was revealed to Raël by one of these creatures named Yahweh, who explained to him the truth of the universe. Claiming to be the leader of the Elohim and the creator of humanity, he reveals that, throughout all of history, he had created a total of 40 Elohim-human hybrids on Earth, who served humanity as prophets - among them being The Buddha, Jesus Christ, Muhammad, and Joseph Smith, with Raël himself being the 40th and final prophet. Raëlians claim that the world entered its current age, the Age of Destruction, in the pre-Event year of 1945, with an event called "the Atomic Bombing", in which a faraway planet called Hiroshima was annihilated by a great explosion caused by humans, after which humanity turned on each other and became dedicated to its own destruction, culminating in the Event itself and their near-total extinction. Raëlians engage in daily meditation, hope for physical immortality through human cloning, and promote a liberal ethical system with a strong emphasis on sexual experimentation, drawing the ire of many of its more traditionalist neighbouring religions.

The Bahá'í Faith is a faith based on the teachings of the antediluvian prophets Báb, and his successor Bahá'u'lláh. They believe in a universalist world view of religion, claiming that there is one God, who is incomprehensible, and whose will has been and will be manifested throughout time in an endless series of revelations and theophanies given to the prophets of man. These Manifestations of God have been revealed to prophets progressively throughout history, unifying humanity in purpose, with interpretations differing according to societal needs. As a result, the Bahá'í are ardent advocates of world peace and unity, with their single greatest goal being that of a single world order where everyone can prosper, regardless of their race, nation, or beliefs.

The Free Baptist Convention was formed after the Event by primarily the various black Protestant churches in the American South though other churches also joined, the most notable of which being the African Methodist Episcopal Church and the National Baptist Convention. Strongly influenced by figures such as Richard Allen, MLK, and abolitionist figures, but most importantly, the Social Gospel, the Convention is extremely diverse, both in beliefs and adherents. The Free Baptist Convention does not forget its roots in slavery, and as such has a rigorous, almost doctrinal emphasis on the civil rights of its citizenry, as well as charity and general pacifism, believing it is every man's duty to bring the Kingdom of Heaven to the world through good deeds and standing up for the voiceless.

The Bezpopovtsy, meaning the Priestless, are a strain of the Old Believer faithful that still stick to their old ways. Having no formal priestly hierarchy, or priests at all for that matter, the Bezpopovtsy completely reject even what little authority the First Hierarch has, instead holding local sermons with the position of priest being most often filled by family or village patriarchs. This lack of organisation has led to the festering of some heterodox practices, such as local scripture, local spirit worship, and most egregiously, self-immolation.

The Penitente Brotherhood of New Mexico is a society of Catholic penitent brotherhoods who believe that the true way to be absolved of one's sins is to suffer as Christ did. These Hermandades are recognised by their characteristic robes and capirotes in long processions through the streets every day of the week. The confraternities themselves are secretive in nature, though any Catholic is allowed to join given they participate in the flagellation required of them. Though the Penitentes have held influence in New Mexico for centuries before the Event, their popularity grew after the fact, many Catholics believing the apocalypse to be a sign from God that humanity has not suffered enough for their sins. Thus, many who believe in the Penitente are also a part of them, their peaceful ways in stark contrast to their scarred bodies.

A faith originating in the wake of the event in the previously extremely atheistic nation of Czechia, Osvicenism is a fusion of both Christian and Buddhist beliefs which had grown significantly in popularity within the nation. Founded by a Czech Buddhist Monk who had been raised a Catholic, he found a way to unite his disparate beliefs together under one system which appealed to the people across Czechia and Goralia. Later this system of belief would spread east by several Monks to the Buddhists of Kalmykia, converting many and becoming a stronghold of the faith. It espouses that while it was to the Buddha that God revealed how one may ascend to heaven, it was only available to the most ascetic of monks, it was only through the sacrifice of Christ that this pathway was made open to all. It views sins such as Pride or Lust as faults which must be overcome by meditation on their meaning and the emotional state which they cause. Only by conquering these faults across multiple lifespans may a person purify themselves and therefore escape the cycle of Birth, Death, Purgatory and Rebirth which all but the most ascetic monks are trapped within. Those ascetics are close to fulfilling their escape to heaven where they will join God as saints.

Bailianjiao or "The Faith of the White Lotus" is a religion of syncretic Buddhist-Manichean origin which spent centuries underground throughout Chinese society only having re-emerged following the event. It awaits the arrival of the Lord of Light and wishes to take control of China to prepare the way for his arrival. Moni is believed to have been the most recent reincarnation of the Lord of Light, other reincarnations include the Buddha, Zoroaster and Jesus. Devout practitioners of this faith practice a vegetarian diet. The Jade Emperor, Sapphire Didact and Ruby Chairmen are seen as evil deities due to their relationship with the successive Chinese states which oppressed those of the White Lotus.

Mojiao is the religion of most Zhuang people. While it has a supreme god, the creator Bu Luotuo, numerous other deities are venerated as well. It has a three-element-theory of the universe: sky, earth and water. Mojiao is animistic, teaching that spirits are present in everything. Moism developed from the prehistoric beliefs of the Zhuang people and it also has similarities to Chinese folk religion, and has developed similar doctrines to Buddhism and Daojiao, in the process of competition with the influence of these religions on Zhuang culture. Mojiao varies from region to region.

Wujiao refers to the various shamanic religious traditions of the Sinitic populations of China. Chinese shamanism is intrinsic to Chinese folk religion and is fairly diverse. Various rituals and traditions are rooted in this belief system, such as Ritual Masters being identified as Wu by outsiders, though most adherents don't self-identify as such. In addition, Daojiao developed partially from Wujiao, as it focused around the pursuit of a long life, or the status of becoming a Xian, otherwise known as a holy man. Having been suppressed and stigmatized in pre-Event China, the religion post-Event had experienced a small revival but remains heavily fragmented. Wuists have generally opted to remain outside of the Daojiao-Liehuo-Sanminshuyi debate regarding the war in Heaven.

Wujiao refers to the shamanic religious traditions of the Sinitic populations of China. Having undergone a great reformation, the Reformed Wuist faith has a semi-codified list of proper rituals and beliefs by combining the most popular ones together, as well as firmly establishing the roles of the Ritual Masters, or Wu as they are sometimes called. Although initially hesitant to participate in the Daojiao-Liehuo-Sanminzhuyi debate, the Reformed Wuists are now actively engaging in such matters. Depending on who leads the faith, it is impossible to say the direction Wuism will take in this regard.

After the Event that struck the world, the Catholic faithful of Asia lost all contact with Rome. Chaos ensued after the acknowledgement of this fact as panicked church leaders and archbishops all around Asia try to re-establish contact with Rome. It took years of looking for and reading rotten antediluvian documents from the years before the Event for the procedure on what to do if this scenario happens. At last, the archbishops around the Philippines and Asia knew what to do, and with the knowledge from the documents and support from other archbishops under the First Council of Manila, the former Archbishop of Manila has been declared Patriarch of Manila, and by extension, all of Asia.

Even before the Event, some schismatic Filipinos wanted to have a seperate Filipino Catholic Church separate from Rome, akin to the Church of England, more known as the Anglicans. Now with the chaos of the Event, the Aglipayans, more centralized thanks to the severed connection of the Philippines and Rome, are now more vocal than ever with their goal of an independent Philippine Church separate from Rome.

The El Shaddai are a herbalistic group that believes in folk healing with herbs and the power of God. Before the Event, El Shaddai was a fringe folk healing group that was formed as a schism with the Catholic Church in the Philippines. Some faithful flock to this sect for the healing of their sickness, while others, mostly tribesmen uncontacted by the Patriarchate, converted to this religion instead thanks to its close ties with the many tribal traditions.

The Sea Creed faith is more a loose group of superstitions from the Atlantic and the Mediterranean. The corsairs of those seas hold together their crews through the fear inspired by the risks of going against the Code of the Sea, and of course against their ruler. Most rulers turn a blind eye on the acts and rituals of the Sea Creed, especially because the Corsairs bring in a fair profit.

For centuries, the waters of the Caribbean have been treacherous to navigate, but even more perilous than the storms and reefs that have doomed men for centuries are the Buccaneers. These are pirates & cutthroats that have stricken fear in the hearts of all that found themselves at the wrong end of a cutlass. According to them, in distant Nassau, the Code of the Sea was drafted by the legendary Flying Gang to manage the savagery of the sea at the dawn of a new age. Indeed, the Buccaneers consider themselves among the very last free people in all the world, living by the final code of laws said to have been drafted prior to the Event, the single aspect of their way of life which distinguishes them from lesser sea-raiders. The Code of the Sea makes no pretense that it codifies anything else besides the customs of pirates, but it is a code which every pirate of the Golden Age of Piracy is said to have had a say in its creation, and accordingly serves as the first tome of holy laws drafted through a democratic fashion. Indeed, even the most powerful captain in the Seven Seas knows that he only rules with the approval of his crew. Today, any who swear upon Neptune's honor may enter into this loose brotherhood as new men, unfettered by all other laws except for those which deal with matters of ship and sail, and to unravel the mysteries of the deep sea and bring succor to those who desire life upon the seas. Indeed, it is said that the fabled Republic of Pirates, the mythical kingdom in which all men were free to do as they please, was the first meritocracy in all the world, will one day be established again once the insidious powers which destroyed it are scoured from the Earth.

Born before the Event on the mountains of Switzerland, some say from a great sage born in the depth of the Alps, the Calvinist faith has greatly grown after the Event. Under rulers chosen by heaven itself (for no ruler that is not chosen could ever be King of the Calvinists for long) the Calvinist faith is prepared to fight to expand the true Christian way.

The Catholic Church in Mexico survived the trials and tribulations of the Event, but not without losses, the biggest of which being contact with the Pope. With no guarantee that the Holy See even exists still, the Archbishop of Mexico City proclaimed himself Patriarch of Mexico, taking his rightful spot in the newly-formed Council of Patriarchs. What came after was total church reform, or rather, the strengthening of its power in the political spotlight. The Patriarchate seized Mexico City and soon started enacting policies of mass religious education, cracking down on public worship of folk saints and syncretic deities, and other similar measures in order to safeguard the Church from heresy and collapse. To the more progressive priests of the Church, these measures were no short of an inquisition, and the pressure boiled over in 2281 AD, when the Mexican Catholic Church officially schismed into two - one half following the Patriarch as the rightful representative of Rome in Mexico, and the other electing their own Archbishop of Mexico City, one with a lot less power, and consequently, a lot less unity.

The survivors of the decrepit metal cities of the old Steel Belt developed an intricate mythology to call their own after the Event. They believe that the world was created by two supreme deities - the organic was created by Gaia, the Mother Nature, and the inorganic was created by God, the Father Industry. In this dualistic balance, the two deities have been in conflict with each other since time immemorial. It was not until Mother Nature created the ultimate invention - life - that one side got the upper hand in this conflict, and the natural world spread without limit, taking over and controlling the inorganic. Industrialists believe that Father Industry then created his own form of life, by crafting the first humans out of clay. He gave them the gifts of thought and intelligence, and taught them how to make fire and how to craft. Thus humanity, the children of the Father, prevailed over Mother Nature, and spread his gifts of metal across the world, creating massive Titans of destruction, flying contraptions, and sky towers. It was not until the ultimate deceit revealed itself - the Black Gold gifted by the Father to power his creation was organic, and when its source was cut off and diminished, the world of man collapsed. Nature took its revenge, leading man to near extinction. Now the world was returned to how it was in the beginning, and the remaining sons of the Father scavenge the ruins of their forefathers, searching for their Lord's gifts and the methods needed to rebuild what is rightfully theirs.

This character is a veteran of an Industrialist Intervention, walking the path of the tycoons of old.

When the Event shook the world to its core, many felt abandoned by their gods. The wayward New English masses got swept by many newfound lodges, occult rituals, and societies preaching freedom of will and body. Whereas the lodges of the north found solace in the sanctity of nature, the lodges of the south instead grew fearful of the dark forces beyond this world, believing the very carelessness displayed is what led to the destruction of the first world. Sacrifices and prayers to the unknown evils grew into elaborate rituals, and the denouncing of lavishness turned into witch hunts for those deemed too sinful, the masses fearing acceptance of such behaviour will lead to mankind's demise once again.\nThe primary belief of the Macabrists is that of The One, the supreme creator. The One is a being beyond human comprehension, credited with being the architect of the universe, the creator of life, and the source of all energy, but also the source of all evil, creating the Devil and his macabre creations. The One is generally believed to have three main aspects - The Light which brightens the world, The Sun as the source of all warmth, and The Word as the source of all knowledge. Thus, The One has many representations, both male and female, including that of the Christian God, Gaia the Triple Goddess, and The Horned God of the Hunt.\nNow, the laypeople of the Macabrist Churches are encouraged to live humble, simple lives, seeking to enter Heaven and reunite with The One who gave them life, while the priests and priestesses most versed in "the Craft" cast magical rituals and wards to keep the mortal world free from the Devil's machinations, unknowable evils seeking to drag souls into hellfire. Black cats, broken mirrors, ravens, and other displays of "bad luck" are considered to open portals to the underworld, leaving people open to demonic possession.

The Old Order Anabaptists are a branch of traditionalist Anabaptist communities that have preserved the traditional lifestyles of their ancestors, such as the Amish, the Old Order Mennonites, and the Hutterites. Their insistence on traditional way of living dates back centuries before the Event and extends not just to social traditions, but reliance on technology, as well as their way of governing. These rules, called the Ordnung, extend to every facet of life, and include dress codes, an insistence on pacifism, the shunning of regular usage of complex and especially Old World technology, as well as insisting that kings rule according to the Bible, not according to Old World documents and constitutions.\nContrary to popular belief, technology use is not prohibited, though the extent of its usage largely depends on community. This wary outlook on progress is the primary factor that helped the Old Order Anabaptists survive the Event relatively well, with them quickly adapting to the new way of post-Event life, and building some of the most stable and prosperous kingdoms of the early post-apocalyptic era. However, the world is progressing faster than the Old Order Anabaptists can keep up, and their way of life finds itself threatened once more.

A wide set of folk beliefs formed after the Event with influences from Christianity and various occult movements, the Arboreal faith believes that the universe and everything in it was created by a single God - a Great Architect, and from his energy emanated all living things. The first life was given to Gaia, Mother Nature, and in her image came the creation of the first humans and the great garden surrounding them. In this garden, however, man was deceived by the Devil, and this corruption of energy led to the creation of many aeons of God, great cosmic beings that never left and still prey on humanity. Man's pride and hubris tested their patience, and the world was struck down as punishment for their arrogance. Now, after the deluge, the Arboreal orders of druids seek to preserve the world as it was designed by the Divine Mother, with regular offerings and sacrifices both to the lesser gods in service of the Architect, and to the Old Ones to keep them away and prevent another apocalypse.

Genevism is a Calvinist movement founded, according to legend, right after the Event during the reign of Emperor Jürgen the Holy. The Genevists are named after the Council of Geneva, in which all Calvinist priests in Europe attended. The Council announced the proclamation of the Calvinist Theocracy as the official form of governance for the Alpereich, which caused a number of priests to storm out, leading to their excommunication and the subsequent founding of the Genevese Church. Following this schism, the Genevese Church eventually took more radical stances regarding Calvinist politics, advocating for total separation of the realm of God and the realms of men. According to the Genevese, all of God's laws cannot be realistically enforced on Earth, and as such Theocracy cannot be the ideal way to govern as it is fundamentally flawed. Though their popularity has waned in the years after the Council, relegating them to near obscurity, Genevese thought may yet be revived once theocratic rule fails the Calvinist faithful.

This distinct sect of Judaism, practiced by the Betah Israeli Jews of Ethiopia has too survived the Event. Their Biblical texts have a few additions to the usual Jewish Bible. After the event, several old customs were revived, such as the unique monastic traditions that differ from the traditions of other Jews.

Zoroastrians worship Ahura Mazda, the uncreated God, as proclaimed by the ancient Iranian prophet Zoroaster. It was the official religion of all Persian empires (except the Hellenic Seleucid Empire) until the Muslim conquest of the Sassanid Empire in 651. The ancient form of the religion involved great sacred hill top fires and the exposure of dead bodies to scavenger birds for cleansing, while the modern form of this religion instead mainly focuses on the following of its primary creed, "Good Thoughts, Good Deeds, Good Words." As such, they are very generous and charitable despite the fact their religion has seriously declined in its number of adherents. The two largest surviving communities can be found in central Iran and Western India, though there was an attempt at revival in the Yarsani Kingdom of Kurdistan in recent history.

Based on a collection of texts uncovered by a Zoroastrian Priest in late 23rd century Tajikistan. This faith holds that the god of time Zorvan is father to both Ahura Mazda and Angra Mainyu and that Zorvan guides humans destiny through various celestial implements. One key difference between this sect and its ancient forebearer is that it contends that Humans must have free will otherwise the command by Ahura Mazda to do good is pointless, thus a divine being would not state such. The faith looks slightly more favourably on Angra Mainyu than traditional Zoroastrianism due to him being one of Zorvan's sons. Additionally they believe that Zorvan's sons must both exist for there to be a universal balance, they believe that there can be no good without evil and no order without chaos to compare it to, while Ahura Mazda is the sibling worthy of worship Angra Mainyu should be respected for the role he plays in the natural order of Zorvan's weave. Because of these beliefs it was driven from its Tajik homeland by its fellow Zoroastrians and the religion found popularity amongst the Sarikoli. The religion generally speaking is not aggressive and if not for it's aggressive neighbours would continue residing amongst its mountain tribes.

Dating back to the early days of Islam, the Qurani believe that Islamic law and guidance should only be based on the Koran, thus opposing any religious authority of the hadiths as well as caliphs. It is their belief that God's message in the Koran is clear and complete as is and that it can be fully understood without referencing outside scriptures. In the post Event era, the Qurani are heavily persecuted and often branded as apostates. They themselves view other Muslims as corrupted and seek to bring Islam back to its original form.

Pusaka, meaning Heirloom, is a term for a new syncretic school of Sunni that has only relatively recently gained a widespread following in the lands of old Indonesia. Born from a combination of Islam and various Indonesian and Malay native beliefs, spirituality, mysticism and shamanism have an important role in the Pusaka faith. Shamans, known as the dukun to Indonesians and the bomoh to the Malay, have an important role in society, considered to be healers and diviners. Weather shamans, known as the pawang, are believed to control the weather and tame wild beasts. There is a special emphasis on ancestral heirlooms, which are believed to house the spirits of ancestors and must be protected, and can give their owners extraordinary powers. Other than venerating the spirits of ancestors, the Pusaka also believe in a wide variety of supernatural entities, ranging from ghosts, known as the hantu, to imps, goblins, and familiars. Despite incorporating a large amount of native beliefs and being denounced by mainstream Muslims as blasphemers and profaners, the Pusaka still firmly consider themselves Muslim, believing that only a powerful and pious Sultan can firmly unite Nusantara once more.

Pesantreni is an Islamic sect originating in Nusantara. It is named after the "pesantren", a type of religious school which played a major role in the spread of Islam within the region. Largely the same as pre-Event orthodox Sunni Islam, the Pesantreni sect has managed to largely avoid internal religious conflict and major distortions to theology in ways of local Malay folklore. Despite outward insistence on religious cohesion and Shafi'i legalism, private worship of Pesantreni Islam tends to have many esoteric Sufist and mystic rituals, including the veneration of ancestral and nature spirits and the religious consumption of cannabis. Nonetheless, the Pesantreni sect still stands tall as the most powerful faith in Nusantara, a position that comes with a theological battle against the syncretic Pusaka sect, a faith which threatens to erase Pesantreni way of life from the history books.

Navayana is a school of Buddhism founded in the decades leading up to the event. Its founder, Bhimrao Ambedkar was born a Hindu, but however following his study of the Buddha's teachings he became convinced of its truth. He found that all currently existing schools of Buddhism had become overly esoteric and no longer thought the Buddha's lessons as he would have wished them. As such he created the "Buddh aur unaka dhamm" which was a recounting of the Buddha's teachings and life with the addition of commentaries added by Ambedkar. This was meant to remove some of the esotericism which had developed in the previously existing sects.

A heresy spawned from just before the event from the theology of Father Matta El Meskeen. He came to blows with the Coptic papacy over the nature of original versus personal sin and the importance of personal faith in god over that of the collective faith in the church. He believed Original sin prior to Jesus was something that an individual could overcome through good deeds and that after the crucifixion one could overcome original sin by either accepting Jesus as their savior or through their own good deeds. As such Mattaists are extremely charitable to their impoverished citizens. He also believed in the total separation of the church and the state such that the church would not interfere with state policies. Overall the importance he placed on personal faith and his critiques of the Coptic church led to Mattaists believing post event that they no longer needed a papacy to govern them.

The Neo-Fraticelli, or 'New Little Brethren', is a Catholic heresy that was inspired by records of a medieval heresy of the same name. It is devoted to poverty and asceticism - especially for men of the cloth. Fraticelli heretics are violently opposed to Church wealth and displays of opulence among the populace. This is due to Mammon Prince of Greed being viewed as the demon King of the Old World, he grew so powerful as to overthrow Lucifer Prince of Pride himself. He brought about the fall of the Old World intentionally therefore the sin of greed is considered as fatal, if not more than, pride. They see the Old World as a society of Pharisees who, instead of helping those in need, separated from them because they bothered their hearts.
Now that Egypt is finally in Coptic hands, we can use this momentous occasion to move the Papal seat back to its ancient home of Alexandria, ending the centuries long exile.

Mandaeism or Mandaeanism, also known as Sabaeanism , is a monotheistic and gnostic religion with a strongly dualistic cosmology. Its adherents, the Mandaeans, revere Adam, Abel, Seth, Enos, Noah, Shem, Aram, and especially John the Baptist. The name 'Mandaean' is said to come from the Aramaic manda meaning "knowledge". Within the Middle East, but outside of their community, the Mandaeans are more commonly known as the Subba or Sabians. The term Subba is derived from the Aramaic root related to baptism, the neo-Mandaic is Sabi. Occasionally, Mandaeans are called "Christians of Saint John".

Legends tell that during the reign of the Romans, Emperor Constantine was blessed by God to save his realm from the invading hordes of Goths and Turks. Many stories were told about this holy figure: some say that he united Europe under his rule after decades of division, others say that he sacrificed himself to save his people from the ravenous Turks. But one thing is certain, and that is on the day of his death, the Angels of the Lord turned him into a statue of marble and hid him under the depths of Constantinople. This is so that in the final days of the world, Constantine could awaken once more to lead the people of God onto salvation as their blessed and immortal emperor.

Neo-Huguenots believe that all rulers are in the service of God, and God only. Any ruler not deemed to serve God and the people are to be named tyrants, and overthrowing them is not only necessary, but a divine right. They believe that if every tyrant is removed from the face of the Earth, eternal prosperity will come to it, and so they try to go on grand campaigns to rid the world of these scum. Neo-Huguenots are heavily inspired by the Monarchomach theorists of pre-event France and consider tyrannicide to be a necessity in the fight for equality before God. They see feudalism as a tool for self-serving monarchs to consolidate more power for their selfish interests, so instead they follow a theocratic government where only the most pious and altruistic get to rule. The Queen of the Thelemites is considered to be the embodiment of a tyrant and her followers demon worshippers, and Novelists are known to have first brought back feudal law after the event, and so both are the main targets of Neo-Huguenot incursions. Catholics and other Protestants are both viewed with heavy distrust, as they both adhere to feudal structures and are also blamed for the destruction of the original Huguenots, a bitterness that never faded.

Neo-Donatists believe that the Last Judgement has come and the people of the world have been found lapse and unworthy of ascension. This means that all people on earth are stained by their sins and have been abandoned by God. The theology of this heresy ponders the implications of the event that destroyed the world of men identifying It, as many Christians did, with the Last Judgement. But in particular, adherents of this branch of Orthodoxy asked themselves if the apocalypse came to the world, why haven't the dead been resurrected and the rightful called at the right of the Father. There are different interpretations of why this happened: some believe that during the Event the apocalypse happened in full, the dead were revived and the children of God judged. What remains of the world today is nothing but the tortures of hell. Others believe that the Event has only heralded the apocalypse and the only reason why the dead haven't been resurrected is that the earth was so full of sin that God rebuked it. Thus, the world now exists as a limbo between the Judgement of God and the damnation of Hell.

A post event religion from across the Atlantic and near the Great Lakes, the Four Guardians faith has a deep connection to the cycles of the world and its natural power. Principally, there are only five truly divine beings in its cosmology, the Five Thunderbirds. The four lesser birds rule over each of the four winds and the greater Thunderbird, their father, rules over all creation. The four seasons of the year are ruled by four demi-gods - Paul Bunyan the Sower of Spring, Minne the Mistress of the Great River, Jack O'Lantern the Headless Bringer of Fall, and Father Christmas, who both rules over winter and delivers the Child, which is a representation of the new year being born following the battle between King Boreas and Vulcanus Rex.

The Aurorean faith is the disparate belief system of the coast and sea-dwelling Alaskans, spread widely across their homeland in the North Pacific, and varying wildly from city state to city state. The faith holds that there are three tiers of great spirits in their pantheon. The greater gods are aspects of Ellam Yua, the spirit of the universe, in the form of the Celestial Ram, the Earthly Ewe, and the Annointed Lamb, are beyond the mortal world of men and are the creators and orchestrators of the Earth, the sky, and all of life's symphonies. The lesser gods, such as the Raven and the Thunderbird, are those who live in the spirit world as mediators between the world of man and the world of gods, and control much of the earthly realm on the greater gods' behalf. Lastly are the various animistic spirits who inhabit the earth, sea, and sky, such as dwarfs and gnomes, and most importantly of all, the Aurorean Heavenly Host, a great army of spirits marching across the sky for which the religion is named. Aurorean shamans attempt to invoke the spirits for good luck, good weather, and bountiful seas, and the vast and elaborate creation stories of the frozen north are frequently retold at potlatches.

A faith hailing from the far shores of Greenland. The inhabitants of those regions adopted most of the beliefs of the Inuits, syncretizing them with the Christian faith. They believe in the sea trinity of Arnakuagsak, Sassuma Arnaa and Nerrivik, the three rulers of the sea. Other gods include the unnamed Røde Sømand, the stone-faced Qooqa and the great Martin Jaegeren, while the evil gods include the wrothful Adlet, the ferocious Amarok and the vengeful Tupilaq. Its followers give great importance to the act of hunting and the respect of the spirits.

column2: The Gallicanist Papacy was formed in the year 2205, with the last Patriarch of Québec proclaiming himself Pope Bien-Aimé I. The Québécois Patriarchate was one of many positions in the newly-formed Council of Patriarchs, meant to hold Catholicism together in total absence of papal contact. Claiming to have received an apparition from the Blessed Virgin, the now-Pope declared the old Papacy forfeit, and forced a massive schism in the Catholic Church of Canada, with many bowing to his word as the new Vicar of Christ, and many more denouncing him as a fraud and a heretic. Ultimately, the Gallicanist Church held its own in the aftermath of ecclesiastical controversy, spawning a new line of American Popes. Whether or not this neo-Catholic Church will survive the eventual backlash of old Catholicism to come its way remains to be seen.

One nation, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all.
Something between a philosophy and a religion, the Constitutionalist faith is one that will bow to no gods, and no tyrants. Those who can be considered Constitutionalist faithful, for they are more zealous in their beliefs than most who are religious, do not bother themselves with prayers, nor churchgoing. The duty of every Constitutionalist is to uphold the values as dictated by the Constitution, which was put together thanks to the Common Sense of Man, as granted to him by Providence when he was first lifted to sapience by the invisible hand of freedom. Those who truly believe in the divine Americana consider the shining city upon a hill to be paradise on Earth, and every free man is entitled to see it prosper under Old Glory.
Though the American Dream had been lost during the First Retreat and many of its lands have since fallen to ignorance and backward zealotry, the Constitutionalists believe that just as America rose all those centuries ago, thanks to the foundations laid by the Founding Fathers, it will rise again like a phoenix from the ashes thanks to those very principles - Pragmatism, Jingoism, Foundationalism, and Transcendentalism.
Because America is an exceptional country founded by exceptional men.

Consisting of what little is left of Catholicism in the lands of the old United States, the Columbian Catholic Church consists of the main Church, led by the Latin Patriarch, and the Mississippian rites, led by the Grandmaster of the Watchers in the Dark. Due to contact with Rome being all but impossible after the Event, the position of Archbishop of Washington was elevated to become the Latin Patriarch, encompassing all Catholics east of Appalachia, and representing them on the Council of Patriarchs. With the Watchers being organised in the 22nd century, they were included under the Latin Patriarchy's jurisdiction as well, but given special autonomy to operate under their own rites.\nSince then, however, the Church has hit a rough patch, with the Church's possessions in the Columbian capital being seized by the federal government, and the Patriarch being forced to retreat to Albany. With the encroaching Constitutionalists wishing to control the Church, the old Catholics of the east turning to heathenry, and the Church in Québec being usurped by a false Pope, only time will tell if the One True Church will survive to meet the Pope in Rome once again.

Mainline Protestantism on United States soil survived the Event with great losses. Formed from all the traditional Protestant denominations in many churches and conventions, it is decentralised and focused on personal salvation. Thanks to the efforts of the High Kings of the Two Carolinas, the Mainline churches favour a more theologically liberal approach, one that has brought them into conflict with the more radical elements of the faith, leading to many wars and skirmishes with the Evangelicals of the Deep South, both sides fighting in the name of the same God. Nonetheless, even after losing much of its follower base to cults of revelation and paganism, the Seven Sisters of American Protestantism will endure as they always have.

The Oriental Orthodox churches hail from the Old World, across the Atlantic and far east of even Rome. When the Event struck, the Church of the East was saved from destruction by the wise guidance of their Catholicos-Patriarch, residing in the ruins of Chicago. Though post-Event Chicago was borderline inhospitable, the zealous Christians defended their Patriarch to the last, the St. George Cathedral standing unscathed to this very day. Since those early days, however, many missionaries have been sent out by the Church, hoping to reach the lost souls of old Columbia who turned to heathenry and paganism, with varying levels of success.

With enough power and control of sufficient holy sites, a Stalinist ruler could declare themselves High Chairman - the supreme spiritual ruler to whom religious and political obedience is owed by all.

It has been many years since any single ruler held enough power to be considered the true Tsar of all the Russias. If we are able to unite the ancestral heartlands of Russia, we may be able to finally revive that august institution in truth.

Where Nobelians believe in the use of Knowledge for peace, Dynamiters consider it a mean to bring glory in battle. This fringe movement claims that war is the greatest of all arts of man, and endeavors to rebuild the great weapons of destruction that made humanity invincible. Following teachings that are believed to come from the great master of war they call the Merchant of Death, they will endeavor to bring back the glory of humanity's power of science, dedicating it to the art of war and destruction.

The Kalevalalaulu faith is an offshoot of ancient Finnish paganism which experienced a resurgence in the lands of Finland and Karelia in the years since the Event. Fusing traditional belief of the Sami, Finnish and Karelian people, the Kalevalalaulu faith is endemic to the region, and focuses more on protecting Finland, Karelia and the lands of the Sami, rather than expanding outwards. Yet, so far no conqueror has ever managed to take those northern lands, and all believers share the faith that it is thanks to the teachings of Ukko and Ilmatar and the bravery of their followers.

Fusing traditional belief of the Sami, Finnish and Karelian people, the Kalevalalaulu faith is endemic to the region, and focuses more on protecting Finland, Karelia and the lands of the Sami, rather than expanding outwards. Now united, the faith is better prepared to defend the homeland and people to Väinämöinen against the Devilmen, the Crown worshippers, the Cross, and any other faith that may come to face them.

A belief system with roots stretching back to the popular culture of the old Russia and Soyuz, Folklorism contains in itself a diverse and sometimes contradictory mythology, mainly centered around Rodina, Patron Goddess of Russians, under whose guidance they conquered everything from Brandenburg to the far reaches of Siberia, her Allies and Enemies and a lot of Lesser Deities such as Prince Nevsky, Visotsky the Bard or Ataman Kudeyar, who are believed to possess magnificent powers which they sometimes grant to mortal followers in exchange for worship.

A religion whose roots stretch back to the popular culture of the old Russia and Soyuz, Folklorism is build and structured upon the pantheon of deities, which is centered around Rodina, Patron Goddess of Russians, under whose guidance they conquered everything from Brandenburg to the far reaches of Siberia. Restructured and cleaned up from unneeded priestly squabble, Mudretist is prepared to withstand the pressure of Tsarsists and Crossmen.

Gelugpa, or 'Yellow Hat' Buddhism is one of the traditional schools of Tibetan Buddhism and has absorbed many of the other schools in Tibet since the Event. It originated from Mahayana Buddhism,and retains many of its traditions,including an emphasis on Bodhisattvas and their intervention in the lives of believers. Traditionally,the Gelugpa are led by the Dalai Lama, but long ago the Panchem Lama was captured by the Chinese, preventing him from recognising the reincarnation of the next Dalai Lama. As a result, the traditional means of selecting the Dalai Lama was abandoned, and he is now elected by a council of Lamas from around Tibet.

Sanminzhuyi is a faith based around the teachings of the great Sapphire Didact found in the book "Principle of Minsheng". The Sapphire Didact rose to prominence in a great war the century before the event during this war 8 great armies of barbarians led by demonic lords arrayed themselves against the Middle Kingdom, slaughtering millions, forcing the Emperor of China to seek divine assistance from the Jade Emperor to fight off these hordes. The Jade Emperor granted his aid to the Middle Kingdom and raised 8 Great Generals to semi-divinity to fight back against the hordes. The Sapphire Didact proved himself to be the greatest of these generals and alongside the sly Ruby Chairman who saw himself raised to full divinity by the Jade Emperor as reward for saving China. However, the Jade Emperor himself had too shown his weakness by allowing these demons to grow so powerful to begin with, and through the wisdom of the Sapphire Didact he concluded that his continued reign would prove disastrous for his beloved China. As such with the assistance of the sly Ruby Chairman he overthrew the Jade Emperor and forced him into hiding for a time. However it would not be long until the Ruby Chairman showed his true colours and overthrew the Sapphire Didact through deceit and cunning, forcing him to retreat to Taiwan. From there he has gradually extended his influence back to the mainland and seeks to reclaim his beloved China for the betterment of all it's peoples and a return to the harmony of the universe.

Liehuo follows the teachings of the Heavenly Ruby Chairman, ruler of the Heavenly Mandate of all. Though once a man, the Chairman ascended to godhood to protect China from the Eight Armies of Evil and the Event to restore harmony to the world after the Jade Emperor was deposed. He fought alongside one of the Jade Emperor's most powerful warriors, The Sapphire Didact, against these eight armies of barbarians and demons. Following their victory these two turned on each other for the throne of heaven and the followers of the Sapphire Didact were banished to Taipei, he still insidiously plots from his island realm among his followers. The Chairman's teachings are left behind in the Red Book for them to follow, so that they might achieve righteousness and not fall to the lies of either the old Jade Emperor or the Deceiving Sapphire Didact. They strongly believe in the obligation to spread the Ruby Chairman's influence to the rest of the world especially the holdouts of the Jade Emperor and Sapphire Didact.

Daojiao is a polytheistic religion originating in China, by the 26th century it is isolated to solely southern China following the rise of Liehuo in the north. While traditionally regarded as founded by Laozi the Supreme Old Lord in the 4th century BC, some elements and practices can be traced to prehistoric folk religions across the Middle Kingdom. The followers revere Tao, the underlying natural order of the Universe  the active expression of Tao for an individual is Te, the inner virtue. Daojiao also value life over death, and believe it possible to achieve immortality, through various methods, including spiritual practices and alchemy. One of its most important dieties, the Jade Emperor, is believed to have been betrayed by two of his servants in the century prior to the event and remains in conflict with them to this day. These two servants were his two greatest generals in the fight against a horde of barbarians led by a series of Demon lords from beyond the middle kingdom, the barbarians and their demon lords proved too mighty for china to overcome without divine assistance. The Jade emperor granted it and lifted 8 generals to semi-divinity they protected china and their two greatest leaders, the Ruby Chairman and the Sapphire didact as they are now known, were raised even higher to the rank of full divinity. But they believed that the Jade Emperor had grown weak to allow these demons to grow so powerful and sought to overthrow him. The religions of Sanminzhuyi and Liehuo represent their followers, this series of events has upset the balance of the cosmos which cannot be restored unless both of these rebellious servants are brought to heel.

The followers of the Jacobinist faith believe that Robespierre, savior of humanity, came to the world to placate the eternal hunger of Madame Guillotine. After the death of her prophet, killed by the ignorance of traitors, Madame Guillotine was left unfed, and in the end it was humanity that paid the price in the form of the Event, when she took all the lives she was denied for too long. The Jacobinists have sworn that this will never again happen. Madame Guillotine shall never again be left without food, no matter the cost. It is a sacrifice of a few for the sake of the many.

The youngest of all Syncretic churches, the Jugoslavist faith was born when the Car of Jugoslavia, hard pressed in keeping his diverse Empire united, made a desperate attempt, calling a great Council of all holy men in his lands, fusing all faiths in his domains in a single religion and forcing them all to accept it or lose their heads. Taking from both the beliefs of Orthodox and Catholics, and additionally from the teachings of the Sunni Prophet, Jugoslavism is still weak, not truly spread outside of the capitals of the nation, where the Kings have more or less begrudgingly embraced the edict of the Emperor. The only one that can strengthen it is the Car of all Jugoslavia.

The Karmapa or 'Red Hat' school of Buddhism was once simply another form of Tibetan Buddhism, considered equally valid alongside the others. However, when the Chinese captured the Panchem Lama, they produced a new Panchem Lama, a Han Chinese man whom they claimed to be the true Lama (called 'the Red Lama' by Tibetans). Most Tibetans rejected this 'new Lama', but some accepted him. This led to a rift in the community, as it was no longer clear who the real Panchem Lama was, thus the traditional means of selecting the Dalai Lama could no longer be used. Those who followed the Red Llama came to be confused with the historical 'Red Hats' school, and now even the knowledge that there used to be another group called by this name has been forgotten.

Katerinist belief states that the Great Holy Spirit and Mother Russia are two equal aspects of the divine energy of the universe, one being masculine and the other feminine. They believe that while the Spirit created the world, Mother Russia created man, and in Her own image gave women the divine power of birth and motherly love. As such, they hold that, just as man is born from a woman, so too were great Russia, its golden age and its glory born from Catherine the Great, the Divine Mother. Katerinists claim that, while every Tsar is blessed by the Spirit, only the Tsarina-Mother was truly divine, and perfect evidence that women are the natural leaders of mankind. Contemporary Tsarists, however, do not believe that Mother Russia is a literal deity, believing the name to merely be a metaphor for the Great Holy Spirit.

A blend of Mongol nationalism and Tengri paganism, Khanism is the belief in the divinity of the great legendary hero Temujin, who in times past conquered the world and gained the title of 'Genghis Khan', or 'Universal Ruler'. Khanists believe that, at the height of his power, Temujin was betrayed by his friend, Han, and cast into the jaws of The Red Menace. Now, they ride ever onward over the plains, hoping to find the Red Menace's cave and free Temujin from his imprisonment.

Laestadianism is a pietistic movement within Lutheranism founded by pre-Event preacher Lars Levi Laestadius. Pietism places especial focus on individual piety and virtue, with Laestadianism advocating for a sinless, spiritual life, free from worldly vices and material greed. Simplicity and worldlessness are important in the every day life of Laestadians, with vanity being frowned upon, as a lavish lifestyle is considered sinful, as well as drinking, dancing, and bodily modifications. If knowingly sinned, a faithful believer should confess to another believer, so that his sins may be forgiven in Jesus' name and blood. In North America, Laestadianism managed to prevail as the largest Protestant sect in the northwest, thanks to its hard emphasis on tradition, though it is to be seen if it will survive, being surrounded by heathens on all sides.

The Church of Enchanted Beings, named after the concept of "väsen", claims to be the successors of millennia old traditions of the European North. Though functionally Christian, centuries of distortion have rendered them a completely separate religion. Emphasis on oral traditions and folk stories have pushed its Biblical aspects into less and less importance, while belief in the supernatural and the hidden has become key parts of everyday life. The unifying part of this folklore is belief in hidden magical creatures, such as gnomes, trolls, and elemental spirits. Protector spirits and patron deities are also frequent and vary from region to region, of note is the presence of several severely distorted Aesir amongst the regional mythologies.

The Einblicker, or the Insightful, are a radical strain of Lutheranism who split off long ago. They adhere strongly to the story of Satanael, an angel who fell in defiance of the corrupt whims of Yaldabaoth, a demonic power who fooled humanity into thinking it was God. Satanael allied itself with the hero Luther who sought out warriors and true believers to topple the pope and his false god. In honour of this story they have moved ever further south, where they are now in majority, ready to pounce on the papist realms before them.

With obscure origins dating back to antediluvian missionaries from Western Europe, Eastern Protestantism is an amalgamation of various Protestant sects with Orthodoxy. Its congregation exists as a loose union of churches formed from the remnants of these ancient missionary activities. Despite the influences, Eastern Protestantism still maintains Orthodox traditions since its inception, and are preformed in the Byzantine Rite. Its adherents also share many commonalities Syriac and Chaldean Churches, which include religious calendars, festivals, and reverence of saints. At the same time, Eastern Protestants also revere Western Protestant figures like Lucas Cranach the Elder, Martin Luther, John Calvin, and Roger Williams.

The Ma'aravim, or the "Westerners" are an amalgam of Jewish sects in America, consisting of Reform, Masorati and Orthodox Jews. The Ma'aravim have long since integrated into the American system and thus are far removed from the affairs of Old World Judaism. The Ma'aravim believe that the only way for the Messiah to eventually come is through 'repairing the world' through Tikkun Olam, a guideline to be righteous, kind and pious.

Originally hailing from eastern Europe, the Hasidic movement has found itself most prevalent in the United States. Initially part of the greater American Jewish community, in time, the Hasidic movement had effectively split from the rest of Ma'aravi Judaism and largely bases itself in more rural Jewish communities across the United States. While they agree about core principles of Hasidic Judaism, many sects have arose following the teachings of several important Rebbes.

The Sharifi school of thought is a sect of Islam from the Maghreb which has developed some heterodox beliefs, especially regarding who can be Caliph. In the chaos of the Post-Event world, many Muslims yearn for a Caliph to unite and defend the Ummah, but nobody has been strong enough and legitimate enough to do so in several hundred years. The Sharifi of Morocco, seeing the power of the Alaouite dynasty, came to believe that an Alaouite could become Caliph, even if he were not of the Quraysh tribe. This position has brought them into conflict with other Muslims, creating a rift in African Islam.
