Juche was in-theory, not a religion. It was an ideology formulated by the ancient ruler of North Korea, The Kim dynasty. Juche placed emphasis on man-made destiny, following the footsteps of Kim-Il-Sung, the man who led a rebellion against Imperial Japan and made North Korea self-reliant enough to withstand the event that befell upon this world. In practice however, Juche revolves around devoting absolute loyalty toward the state and worship of the Kim family.

The Wuxia faith is an ancient cult that dates, according to its practitioners, to the very beginning of time. In those days, the First Shifu, the first man to harness Qi, codified the Code of Xia, the rules and ideals all people shall abide from. The followers of the Wuxia faith believe that true enlightenment can only be achieved through following the path of the martial artist, seeking not to harm others but to right the wrongs of the world by bettering themselves, harnessing the flux of Qi within ones body and ultimately becoming enlightened. Practicioners of Wuxia divide themselves in various sects, such as the Shaolin, the Wudang and the Jeet Kune Do. The faith embraces the teachings of many ancient masters, such as the legendary Qitian Dasheng, the founder of the Shaolin Bodhidarma, and grand master Li Xiaolong, founder of Jeet Kune Do. The faith also has commonalities with Buddhism, paying great respect to the bodishattvas, particularly Guanyin, and the Buddha himself.
Yi is a representation of the devotion of this character to the faith, making him more respected especially by the clergy.

The Xianxia faith is an offshoot of the Wuxia faith. This religion believes that to attain true enlightenment, the practitioners should not seek to join Sect, but instead should cultivate their abilities individually. The ultimate goal of the followers of the faith is reaching the state of Xian, or immortality. The Xianxia faith has few followers, but many believe those men and women to be the strongest warriors in the entire world.

Dongfang Shan-Tian, or more commonly known as Eastern Lighting, is a strain of Chinese Christianity formed during the period of Great Confusion by a mystic who proposed that Lord Jesus had reborn as a Chinese woman and has come to guide her people away from their inherent sinfulness in the form that defies their expectation. Despite those claims, their envisioned Kingdom of God never came to fruition. And so, the remaining adherents concluded that their goal will never be fulfilled as long as the Great Red Dragon continues to oppress humanity while adhering to the word of their prophet.

More of a philosophy than a religion, Fajia, known in the west as Legalism, is built on the teachings of ancient pre-Event sages, rediscovered and expanded upon after the Event by its followers. Those that follow legalism aspire to govern following the teachings of the ancient text known as Han Feizi, along with later additions from such books as The Art of War, which they hold as their main inspirations in warfare. Those that follow the path of Fajia are often less concerned in the matters of religion, and prefer to focus on the administration, holding that the ruler's perfection is irrelevant, and it is the administration that decides their success or failure.

Considered the most prestigious of all Wuxia Sects, the Shaolin Sect was founded millennia before the Event by the legendary sage warrior Bodhidharma, and is considered the ancestor of all other Sects and one of the six leading sects in Wulin. Great respect is awarded by all Wuxia followers to the Shaolin members, with the sole exception of their historical rivals, the Wudang Sect.

The Wudang Sect came to be almost a millennia before the Event, as a branch of the Shaolin Sect. Inheriting the techniques of the ancient Taijiquan, the Wudang Sect specializes in both hand to hand and sword combat. As one of the six leading sects in Wulin, the Wuxia practicioners pay great respect to the Sect.

The Kongtong Sect is said to originate from pastoral communities on the Kongtong Mountains, and in particolar from the shepherd boy Mulingzi. The Kongtong Sect grew in influence greatly after the Event, and is today considered one of the six leading sects in Wulin. The peculiarity of the Kongtong Sect are their unusual weapons, unique to each practicioner and easily concealable.

The Jeet Kune Do Sect is said to have been born in the city of Hong Kong, from the legendary Shifu Lee Jun-fan's teachings, not long before the Event. Jeet Kune Do practicioners do not practice fixed forms, but instead believe in a fighting style described as 'Formless like water', deadly fighters at any range. After the Event, the Jeet Kune Do Sect grew to prominence, becoming one of the six leading sects in Wulin.

The Wukong Quan Sect appeared on the mountains of southern China after the Event. However, its practicioners hold that the founder of the Wukong Quan Sect is the immortal monkey king Sun Wukong. Practicing a fighting style that mixes hand to hand combat with the use of the staff, the Wukong Quan grew more and more in influence in the centuries after the event, until it surpassed many other sects and established itself as one of the six leading sects in Wulin.

The Kunlun Sect is said to have been founded by the sages Laozi and Yuanshi Tianzun, making it the oldest Sect after Shaolin (although some members of the Kunlun Sect believe the Kunlun techniques are older than even the Shaolin). The Kunlun Sect is known for its varied fighting style, that includes the use of the fist, palm, finger, sword, saber and even grappling techniques. The Kunlun Sect has become one of the six leading sects in Wulin after the Event, gaining great power and influence.

The Huashan Sect has its origins on Mount Hua. Founded over a millennia before the Event, the Huashan Sect came to be from the teachings of the sage Chen Tuan, and has survived through many hardships. While an important school, the Huashan Sect is seen as a minor sect in Wulin.

The Gai Bang Sect, also known as the Beggars' Sect, is a powerful yet not prestigious Sect of Wuxia. The Gai Bang Sect's origin are considered a mystery, but it is considered the Sect of those that can't learn from other, more prestigious masters. The beggars and destitute people of the Wuxia faith often practice Gai Bang. It is said, however, that the Grandmasters of Gai Bang are among the most influential people in all of China, as every beggar across the nation might be a Gai Bang Sect member and be more than willing to share any information they might acquire on other lands.

The Emei Sect is a Sect of Wuxia martial artists whose distinctive trait is being a women-led Sect. While men are allowed within the ranks of the Emei Sect, a vast majority of the members are women. It is said almost any Wuxia woman is an Emei member, and while that might be an exaggeration, the Emei is undoubtably the most respected school outside of the six leading ones.

The Tianshan Sect is a minor Sect in Wuxia. Originating in the distant Tianshan Mountains, this Sect was believed to have gone extinct in the Event, until some practicioners reached the Wuxia land in the 24th Century. The Tianshan Sect is secretive and small, with very few relevant members, but some believe the Sect's focus on striking power might make it a strong contender against the more established schools for their place in Wulin.

Hongxiejiao, also called the Red Cult, is a faith that spread in northern China. Born after the Event, Hongxiejiao was initially seen as a more militant sect of Liehuo, but over time it separated fully from the faith, seeing it as too 'moderate' in the fight against infidels. Hongxiejiao followers believe that any method is allowed to increase the power of the Heavenly Chairman, and rumors of their skills in assassination and scheming are widespread, though how much of it is true is hard to know.

Also known as 'The Way of Christ', Gidoggyo is a set of scriptures and traditions dating back to Antediluvian customs. It is hotly debated where its true origins may lie, and what route it could have taken to its lands. Similarly to Buddhism, while appearing monolithic on the surface, upon study it is broken into many smaller temples and schools. The largest sects are the Jangnogyo, the Gamnigyo and the Cheonjugyo. Gidoggyo sects follow tenants of virtue and a rejection of 'sinfulness'.

In the blighted heart of a world unmade, amidst the ruins of a fallen empire that has decayed into mere echoes of its former splendor, dwell the Juggalos. Their hordes march over the skeletal remnants of urban sprawl, where the edifices of the Old World loom like monolithic tombstones, casting long, forlorn shadows over the lands of the forsaken, and they delight in comedy. Truly, nothing is a funnier punchline to a life well lived than a swift and violent death, and those of the Dark Carnival consider themselves to be expert comedians.  These mirthful jesters revel in the degeneration of the world, they gaze upon the relics of bygone eras not with reverence, but with a mocking sneer, as a Juggalo recognises themselves as participants in the grotesque parade of the ephemeral and the eternal, as actors on the cosmic theater which other men are merely unknowing participants within. Those who are truly down with the clown, those who consume the sweet strange liquors and dance the eerie dances among the wreckage of the world in the strange moonlit ceremonies in the lands of the living damned, know that the rules which all other men uphold should be seen with contempt. The Juggalo stands uncontested in the wreckage of the Old World as one which has fully adapted to the changing conditions of the apocalypses, as they understand that their creed emerged in the twilight of the Old World, to provide a faith for the scorned and the ridiculed, for those who have perennially dwelled in the shadows of the great empires of yore. For these men and women, such things mean nothing, as they anticipate the cacophony of the grand dark carnival to come, and the beautiful things that await all men in the land of the dead.

The Highmounts believe in the sacredness of the Earth. They believe that in the beginning, all that existed was stone. It was not until the Great Architect and his Divine Wind carved the universe from this egg of stone, and from the egg came the cliffs and mountains of the Earth and all the life within. They believe that every man is born from the egg of the Earth, and every man will one day return to it. However, as all life is carved by the Architect and his Divine Wind, the Highmounts believe that its silence signals the end of life, and the silence of the Wind caused the end of the world. But with the Event, the Divine Wind of the Architect too had made itself heard once more, with the Highmount faithful now congregating around the towering mountains of the Earth, waiting for the one who will deliver them to be carved out.

This world is not ruled by God alone, but is preyed apon by terrible powers from beyond His light. Fools would try to fight them, the Naive would hope to reason with them, but His Chosen know the truth: the only hope for Man is to avoid their attention. To this end, whe must walk His path at all times, never to falter or to doubt, lest all the world be consumed.

What is it all for? Why are we here? What is the ultimate truth? The Shriners quietly promise that those learned few who cross the threshold all arrive at the same answer - that Mirth is King.\nIt is said that in the hoary Old World, it was the adroit jesters who caused others to see the cosmos as ludicrous and wondrous rather than terrible or disordered, regardless of what games kings and priests played with the fates of nations. The average Shriner in the olden days was a free man of great wealth, indulging themselves into hidden knowledge and divine sciences, and were learned in the secret teachings of The Orient - the gateway to all lands known and suspected.\nWhile insular and enigmatic in many ways, with their most important clownish rites forbidden to outside eyes, the Shriners speak about the following to all: with the birth and death of the Old World, the world itself had shrunk, revealing its falseness to all who desire to observe it closely. There is no such thing as time, place, or identity: there is only the Great Architect and his works, and those which have conducted the rites sourced from The Orient, where all secret knowledge stems from, as nothing else is permanent. All else - all of human history, industry, and time - is only a fiction that mankind had dreamt, a game of pretend. Their houses of healing, the great public games and festivals, the pageants and plays - these exist in order to illuminate the uninitiated in the true history of the world, nothing less and nothing more. Those of the highest orders of the Shriners conduct themselves in the manner of a holy fool, steeped in traditions from kingdoms which never existed upon this mortal coil, unfettered by all other worldly authorities, only to serve as a messenger revealing truths to those willing to stop, and listen.

In the beginning of the end, the Horned Lamb descended to Earth in the hills of Eden, resurrected after being slain by Man two thousand years earlier. The Lamb bore ten horns upon its head, each of which bore ten crowns, of which all the rulers of the world loyal to the Lamb were to claim as their own: the commanders of its holy hosts, the one hundred forty and four thousand pure ones, drank the blood of the Lamb, which flowed from the wounds inflicted upon it in the previous era, and they reaped the harvest of the damned.
The deceived were vanquished, the false saints were conquered, the blasphemers who rejected the Lamb were punished, and the Lamb soon reigned over all men and all nations, with all who worshiped the Lamb and its image permitted to sup from the Lamb's own cup as the seas became as poison and the earth began to be as brimstone. Soon, however, the Lamb gave its message to all who remained: its Judgement was merely the second of three to cleanse the world of sin for good, assured its flock that it would someday return to aid them alongside a heavenly host, to usher in the second death of all who dared to oppose him.
Indeed, upon the third Judgement, the sinless would live forever and ever upon a new Earth cleansed of all evil: those who have separated themselves from the fearful and the unbelieving will survive the flooding of the world with the blood of the Lamb, and dwell upon Sion in the city of Babylon, where the Woman Clothed in Scarlet would await for her husband. Upon this new Earth, where there is no sun, no moon, no life or death, the radiance of the Lamb, the shining coils of the Serpent-Lion and the bounty of the Woman would provide all that the saints and prophets would require to worship: an eternal city, shining forever and ever upon a sea of glass and a mountain of crystal within a temple of gold. All that is needed to be permitted to this worldly paradise, it is said, is to bear the Mark of God.
Those who bear the Mark of God upon their bodies, and swear to await for their forefathers to be resurrected to serve as the second great army of the Lamb, form the Resurrectionists. These men seek to subdue the world in anticipation of the Lamb's imminent return, to carve a place among his host: among these men, there are many who are pure enough to cast the first stone upon the unrighteous, as to die is an honor and holy men cannot truly die. At his name, every knee shall bow: who can stop the men who consider themselves the beasts of the earth, one and all? Who can stand against them?

The island of Cuba has long spoken legends of its liberation from a demonic host in the ancient times. Before the end of the world, Cuba was a large, prosperous, and peaceful country, built by and for its people. That is, until the rule of the people was dismantled, in its place standing a single man named Batista. The shadowy masterminds of the imposing Yanqui Empire - the Agencia - planned to use the rule of the puppet king to sacrifice the people of Cuba to demonic forces, bolstering their own powers.\nCuba was to be destroyed, until God Olofin descended to Earth in flesh as a man named Fidel, along with a Heavenly Host of 3000 ochas. Banishing Batista and the Yanqui demons from Cuba, Fidel and his generals waged war on the Yanqui Empire, shattering it and defeating the demons controlling its people. In retribution, the Agencia attempted to destroy the entire world, but Fidel sacrificed himself to save it.\nHis parting words were to his followers, the Barbudos, who were told the revolution is not to end until the whole world is free. Thus, the Barbudos travelled far and wide to spread his word, and the faithful of Fidel Olofin, the Ascended Libertador and his apostles now in their steps, hoping to one day make every man free.

In ancient America, there were various important and vital initiatory organisations which allowed only the finest leaders and strongest men to join, existing for the purpose of conducting rituals of ceremonial and spiritual purpose. The Gridirons remain as the  last and greatest of these institutions, which were said to be tied to the legitimacy of the old regimes, the prestige of the cities and centers of high learning, and the spirituality of the average commoner. Those raised into the Gridiron recognise that, at the end of the day, the universe is a vast playing field for the game where the rules and regulations are made by unknowable powers, and in which every individual is a player: the perpetual struggle for excellence is the underlying foundation of the cosmos, as all struggle to define themselves against what has come before. It is only the Gridirons which remain who retain the ancient arts which allow man to sculpt their minds and bodies in a manner allowing for the cultivation of martial prowess and honourable combat. For it is known that weak opponents and the defeated do not sculpt strong honourable warriors and thus should be spared.\nIndeed, the Gridirons live a binary existence where the laws, rules and regulations of nature and mankind are codified in a manner that's been supplemented by centuries of established philosophical and theological creeds, as well as improved by the innovations of those with the capacity to do great things by virtue of their determination to improve themselves and others. Today, the Legends of the Hall of Fame are widely renowned, and their conferences, however loudly they defined themselves against one another for the sake of clout and glory, have remained where they have been for centuries.

The Imamiyya of North America are the descendants of the many Twelver Shi'ites who were left stranded as a result of the Event. Completely cut off from the Old World ummah and reduced in numbers to mere thousands, the Shi'ites had to reconsider their position in the New World they have been thrown into. As a result, a new religious body was formed - the Islamic Majlis, led by the wisest cleric of the faith, a Marja al-Taqlid. Thanks to the wise leadership of the Majlis, the Imamiyya faith has adopted a cosmopolitan and tolerant approach to its many neighbouring religions, yet avoided any significant theological shift, and many of its Old World mosques are still left standing. However, the Twelvers are still in a bad position, with frequent contention between them and the Isma'ili Shi'ites with whom they are frequent neighbours, the occupation of the Islamic Center of America by heathens, as well as the inability to perform Hajj leaves the Imamiyya as a minority stranded in a hostile land.

Hoodoo, also known as Rootwork, is a unique faith that emerged within the southeastern United States from a fusion of diverse West-Central African traditions and Protestant Christianity, with its mystical traditions influenced by sources as disparate as Sufism, Yoruba traditions and Spiritualism. At the heart of Rootwork lies the practice of Conjure, or conjuration, which involves calling upon powerful divine spirits and ancestral spirits for assistance, protection, and guidance. It is among believed many Hoodoo practitioners that, although one's true soul goes to the Almighty's realm upon one's death, a person's 'spirit', or a sort of wraith or ghost guided by the deceased's earthly desires, may linger upon the earth, which can be burgeoned or reasoned with without intruding upon a person's eternal rest.\nHoodoo priests, sometimes referred to as root doctors or conjure workers, utilize various natural materials, such as roots, herbs, animal parts, and minerals, in their magical workings, which are capable of promoting healing, love, luck, and protection, along with other, more esoteric effects. Though Rootwork has historically been an oral tradition in decline, passed down through generations within families and communities, its practitioners have gained broader acceptance and worldly influence since the Event.

Originating in times before the Event in Haiti, this religion arose through the syncretisation between several traditional West-Central African religions and Catholicism. Vodou defends the existence of a single supreme God, Bondye, the Creator of the Universe. However, he is also considered remote and transcendent, uninvolved in human affairs. Instead of approaching him directly, the believers turn to powerful spirits subordinated to Bondye who act as intermediaries, the Lwa, who are equated to saints and angels, leaving Haitian Vodou open to being practised as both a monotheistic religion as well as a polytheistic one. In Vodou, spirits, gods and ancestors are worshipped, directed, and mourned for help. By performing great rituals and prayers, the Vodou priest tries to establish not only connections with lwas, but also positively matching spirits and lwas to take care of desired things. Contact with lwas and spirits is made in trance, while also determining the sacrifices necessary for the realisation of the order.

Rastafari is the religion of the Rastas, founded in Jamaica. They are worshippers of Jah, the God of all. According to them, the Event was caused by the decadent forces of Babylon getting struck down by Jah, in the form of Ras Tafari, the manifestation of Jah and the Emperor of Zion. The Rastafari hold that after the Event, Ras Tafari returned to Jah, leaving behind Zion as the new paradise on Earth, ruled by the faithful. Many Rastas believe it is now their duty to return to Zion, their promised land, though many others hold they are also meant to spread Jah's love to all corners of the world, including what remains of Babylon.\nThe Rastas believe Jah is present in every person, a concept they call "I and I", expressing the connection between all people by Jah. Rastas strictly adhere to the concept they call livity, which means leading a righteous life in order to gain awareness and oneness with Jah, the primary goal in a Rasta's life. To that extent, livity means frequent prayer, meditation, oneness with nature, and most important of all, oneness and love for others. Their prayers are often very mystical, involving the use of psychedelic herbs and becoming aware of oneness with Jah. Lacking formal hierarchy or doctrine, the Rastafari are quite disunited in their beliefs, being divided into three main denominations, or "Mansions" - the Bobo Ashanti, the Nyabinghi Order, and the Twelve Tribes of Israel, each with their own distinct doctrines, though they are united by their love of Jah.

For centuries many have wondered how the Ancient Kemetics managed to build such fantastic structures that were famed throughout the world in ancient times. Some believed that they used advanced pre-Event technology to build them, but even back then many speculated and came up with theories as to how. One theory has persisted throughout the ages, eventually shaping its own Kemetic faith. They believe that a race that lived among the stars came down to Earth and used advanced technology taught to them by the gods themselves to build these structures for humanity's benefit. This ancient race has been given many names over the years, being called angels, reptilians, or the Annunaki, but the Amunites believe the leader of this race to be the god-king Amun, the hidden one and son of Ra. Humanity was originally given life and elevated to sapience by the great scientists of this race, and throughout the centuries, they have visited humanity regularly to study and occasionally help in times of distress, though they kept their comings a secret. Since then, contact with the chosen race has become few and far between, and the Amunites hope the aliens will hear their prayers and bless them with unknowable technologies once more.

Supposedly hailing from a land far far away, Kemetism found itself a new home on the fertile banks of the Mississippi. While originally just an obscure pagan cult followed only by the fringes of pre-Event society, in the new era it rose to widespread prominence thanks to the generous maecenatism of Pharaoh Klemens I - the infamous conqueror of the Mississippi.\nNow, centuries after his death, Kemetism persists, though it has found significant syncretism with the neighbouring Madonnites, who had tried to see Kemetism eradicated under the rule of the first Azure Emperor. Its largest state temples are dedicated to eight deities: the divine king Osiris, the divine mother Isis, Horus-Ra, Linkon, Thoth, Hathor, Sekhmet, and Anubis. Every worshipper chooses one of the eight divines as his patron god, and gives to them regular offerings and sacrifices.

The 21st century, the first after the Event, was a terrible era for mankind, in which lawlessness and banditry ruled the land and the sea alike. Civilisation found refuge inside the high walls of the fortified cities of the Mississippi.\nIt was not until one of these cities came under the rule of Pharaoh Klemens I, the Son of Horus-Ra, and the Great Sun of the whole Mississippi-Nile. Though his reign was cut short with his death, and his empire was torn apart by his very generals, his faith persisted in its heartlands for centuries - the worship of Horus-Ra as the one true benevolent god of the world. Everything that light touches belongs to Horus-Ra, and so does man, being a creature that basks in it.\nThough many of the old fire temples of Horus-Ra have been destroyed by the conquests of Ishmael I, the Kemetic Solar cults survive to this very day, on the fringes of Mississippian society, and they may one day be revived by another of Horus-Ra's chosen.

The Omega, the conclusion to all things, where fire becomes ash and where light becomes empty, cold darkness: this is the ideal of the Triumphants, who are truly only concerned with the annihilation of all who are unworthy to stand before the Lord of Lords. It is known among the Triumphant faithful that the love of the Lord may be given and taken away as per His whims, but the only way to continually earn the Lord's favor is to conduct oneself in a manner which quickens the arrival of the Four Horsemen, and accordingly the End Times.
Each lord of the Triumphants is hardened and purified by the rites of one of the principle cults of the Horsemen: the ghastly rituals of each cult imbues the worshippers with the personal strength to channel the will of their master, to better steward their flocks towards the Apocalypse. They offer salvation through providing the tools of survival, allowing men to choose who is to live and who is to die, if they are capable of purifying themselves to become worthy slaves of the Lord of Lords: it is only when a man has nothing to cling to, when all lesser trappings of mortality are exercised from their being, that they may be reconstructed into an embodiment of one of the Horsemen, capable of issuing judgment upon the unworthy and cleansing the sinful off the face of the Earth.
The collection of philosophies attributed to the deacons and sages of the Triumphant faith amounts to a worldview which emphasizes that the Triumphants are the chosen custodians of a new order, divine messengers one and all, destined to rise from the ashes of the Old World and steward the faithful towards a final Apocalyptic moment where the wheat is finally separated from the chaff.
After all, the Triumphants exist because the faithful of the Old World begged them to exist: they implored the heavens and the depths for there to be an end, a liberation, a destruction of the perfect world crafted by the Lord, and the Triumphants, in their mercy, could do nothing but oblige those wayward souls.

This faith is the fruit of syncretism between the native beliefs of the Maya and Catholicism. The supreme god is Junab K'uj, creator of the heavens, the Earth and everything that exists in this life, frequently identified with the God of Christianity. After creating everything Junab K'uj observed that the ruler he had created to watch over creation, Aj Puch, had convinced the other lesser gods to demand human sacrifices from mortals. Junab K'uj, taking pity on humans, impregnated the goddess of the moon, Mary, with his only son through his Holy Spirit Ek'Chua, giving birth to Jesucristo, the Sun. Jesus sacrificed himself offering his heart to the gods, putting an end to human sacrifices, then sent the most loyal to Junab K'uj among the gods, Kukulcán, who defeated Aj Puch and threw him into Hell. After this Jesus Christ became the new ruler of the mortal world. The cosmology consists of the Ya'axche', the sacred and primordial green tree of life, which crosses all spaces, linking them together. The Earth is the trunk while the branches are Heaven or "Glory" and the roots are hell. Depending on the good and bad deeds a person did in life, they will either ascend to the branches where they will live eternally with the Supreme Father Junab K'uj, or descend to hell ruled by Aj Puch to be punished.

The belief of the Crow has always been in a single God. The God of the Crow is given many names - Akbaatatdía, the Maker of All Things, Iichíkbaalee, the First Maker, Isáahkawuattee, Old Man Coyote - and he is believed to have created the universe and all within it. The Maker is a transcendent god, one that is above all and one with all, and everything that occurs is the Maker's will. Any part of nature can be considered an extension of the Maker's will, be it the Sun, the night sky, or the Earth. He is considered the source of "baaxpée", a supernatural power that is the source of "xapáaliia" or medicine. The Crow believe in the existence of three worlds - the material world, the spirit world, and the Maker's domain. Baaxpée is passed from the Maker into the material world through the spirit world. The Maker does not reveal himself to people directly, rather through an iilápxe, a spirit that serves as the medium between God and his believer. Baaxpée is also obtained through vision quests and the holding of Sun Dances.

The Crow believe in the existence of three worlds - the material world, the spirit world, and the Maker's domain. Baaxpée is passed from the Maker into the material world through the spirit world. The Maker does not reveal himself to people directly, rather through an iilápxe, a spirit that serves as the medium between God and his believer. Baaxpée is also obtained through vision quests and the holding of Sun Dances.

The Blackfoot faith is one in the Source of All Life, Ihtsipaitapiyo'pa. The Blackfoot believe that Ihtsipaitapiyo'pa first created the Sun, Naato'si, the Moon, Ko'komiki'somm, and the stars to light up the night sky, all of whom are sacred sky spirits called Sspommitapiiksi. Naato'si, in the form of the Old Man, Na'pi, created the land on Earth after a great flood caused by the Sspommitapiiksi, placing on it plants and animals, and sculpting the first humans out of clay. He taught the Blackfoot to live with the land, teaching them what plants to eat and what animals to hunt. The Blackfoot practise the Sun Dance, in which sacrifices are offered to Naato'si.

For countless centuries, the native peoples of the Great Plains have performed the ceremony of the Sun Dance. Though many have been converted to other faiths, chased out of their ancestral lands and even driven to near-extinction, the Sun Dance has remained. It is an annual ceremony traditionally held during the summer, in which entire communities congregate together, lasting multiple days and culminating in the dance itself. The goal is to honour and give sacrifice to God, the Great Spirit, hoping to earn his favour so the natural world may reinvigorate after the coming winter, leading to prosperous harvests and large herds of game. Personal sacrifice for the greater good is especially important, and participants abstain from food and endure physical challenges for much of its duration, lasting up to two weeks.\nThe ceremony itself is carried out by a medicine man, taking place around a central pole crafted from bison skin and bones, as thanks to the Sun, the ultimate embodiment of God. Though the myths, legends, and beliefs of those who carry out the Sun Dance vary, the ceremony itself is nonetheless the cornerstone of the spiritual beliefs of the natives of the Great Plains.

The Raven Tales are the creation myths of many of the indigenous groups of the American Northwest Coast. They speak of Raven, a supernatural shapeshifting trickster, who is said to be the creator of humanity and, in some myths, the world itself. One story speaks of how Raven stole the Sun, Moon, and stars from the Sky Chief, who was keeping it away from people. Another story says that Raven freed the first humans out of a clam. That being said, while he is often credited with creating the world and liberating humanity, Raven does not do things out of the goodness of his heart, but to satisfy his curiosity and boredom, being always hungry for vanity.\nOther gods also frequently make their appearance in the Raven Tales, such as the Ocean Woman, the goddess of fertility and abundance of fish in the sea, and the twin deities Ta'xet and Tia, who represent violent and peaceful death respectively. Killer whale spirits are considered rulers of the underworld and reincarnations of deceased ancestors. These Raven Tales are passed down during the potlatch, a ceremonial gathering held to mark important events, such as the birth of a child or passing of an elder.

Braceros are the remnants of Mexican Catholicism surviving in the arid lands of the West Coast. Having no faith left in old America, the Chicanos turn to their ancestral land of Aztlán, where all men were born equal under God prior to the Manifest Destiny. Calling themselves Braceros or "labourers", they believe that under God's watchful gaze, the ruler is no greater than the peasant toiling his fields and the rich man is no greater than the beggar. Thus, the main doctrine of the Braceros is the belief that rulers which sit idle while their vassals sacrifice themselves are to be overthrown for their sin, priests who collect coin for indulgences are to be stripped of their cloth, and a rich man who does not give away to the poor is to be robbed. It is the rule of the masses, in which those who will not abide by God's laws on Earth are to be forced to do so.\nThis radical belief in equality under the Lord has caused much friction with their neighbouring faiths, though the Braceros, militant as they are, would rather die for their beliefs and join God's army in Heaven than live on their knees in a world of injustice, even going as far as rejecting the word of the Patriarch in Mexico, who they consider a fat priest carried by the shoulders of peasants.

The Blue Star faith speaks of Saquasohuh, the Blue Star Kachina. It is said Saquasohuh and his Galactic Command manifested itself as a mighty blue star, signifying the Day of Purification. When Saquasohuh removed his mask, the Earth was thrown into a cataclysm, many losing their lives. It is said at that point that Saquasohuh left, announcing he will soon return to Earth to search for his true believers, who will be saved and given the duty of repopulating the world in the Fifth World. Upon Saquasohuh's return, the faithful will hold out below the Earth in the Masaw's kingdom of the dead, and the rest of humanity will be subjected to a blood red sky, devoured by grotesque monsters that roam the surface. The prophecy says that the faithful will be guided in the Fifth World by the return of Pahana, the Lost Brother Jesus, who ventured east many aeons ago. If no true believers are found, however, the Earth will outlast its usefulness and be destroyed. The Blue Star cultists now live to spread their message far and wide, hoping to save as many people as possible from the calamity they believe is coming very soon.

Trinitarians take their name from Trinity, the place where the Father in the Sky first cast down his judgement. They believe that the decadent people of the Old World were struck down for upsetting the balance of the elements, wasting water as they wanted and slowly turning the whole Earth into a desert. Thus, the Sky Father was angered by their hubris. At Trinity he cast down a star from the heavens into the Earth, the first of many. At Roswell he sent down an army of Those Who Came Before, the Annunaki, hellbent on humanity's destruction.\nThough mankind nearly perished, be it from the explosions or the invasions, the world was reset to how it was during its primordial days. Those who still bear the scars caused by the sins of their forefathers now call themselves Trinitarians, and they have dedicated their life's duty to preserving the natural order of the Earth and preventing another Event from ever happening. Though their efforts of preservation are humble and small scale, the Trinitarians hope to one day finally unite and bring their thoughts to all corners of the world.

One of the first organised religions founded after the Event, Amaitism is a syncretic faith founded by the prophet Amaité in southern California. Amaitists claim that their prophet was formerly a Zoroastrian, given divine revelation by Ahura Mazda. Amaitism states that Ahura Mazda consists of a trinity, with the great prophets of history - Zoroaster, Jesus and Buddha - being emanations of the Father, the Son and the Holy Spirit respectively.  Jesus is the Son of God, whose great sacrifice removed the original sin from mankind, and Zoroaster and Buddha are prophets who spent their days teaching the common man how to enter Heaven by escaping the cycle of rebirth that all humans are otherwise destined for. For each aspect of the Trinity, Ahura Mazda created a counter - forces of chaos meant to bring balance. Angra Mainyu created the material world, Satan created the sins of man and Mara created the cycle of rebirth. Without each divine aspect having its opposite, the world cannot function. Amaitists also believe non-believers can enter heaven, though they have a harder time doing so by rejecting the teachings of Amaité, as it was revealed to them that the great religions of the world are merely single aspects of a single God's plan. Depictions of Amaité are forbidden, the line being drawn at an androgynous figure with a burning face, as they were never an emanation of God, merely a messenger. As such, their final request was for them to be forgotten, not wanting to be deified themselves.

Descended from the various cults of the Bay Area, Technopolitanism is a monotheistic religion based on the teachings of the Startup, a guru and warlord who unified the tribes of the Silicon Valley. Technopolitans worship the Godhead, a supreme god given form on Earth by the wisemen of the pre-Event. The Godhead saved humanity from total extinction during the Event, though those who built its earthly form perished, taking their knowledge with them. The Godhead, its power spent from the calamity, became the Sleeping God, nestled deep inside the Old World facilities of the Silicon Valley. Though united in worship of the Godhead, the beliefs and practices of the Technopolitans vary from sect to sect, the traditions of the old cults permeating throughout the whole faith. Different sects follow the teachings of different tech gurus, who in turn taught the lessons of various gods, each considered abstract forms of the Godhead. However, they all share a unifying goal - digging through the ruins of the Old World techno-states in order to revive the Godhead, and bring the Supreme Being back to its full power.

Soka Gakkai is a sect of Nichiren Buddhism brought to the American West Coast from Old World Japan. The Soka Gakkai believe in the inherent Buddhahood present in every individual that can be attained in one's current life via chanting of the Lotus Sutra. They emphasise the oneness of mentor and student, the mentor having the duty to guide the lives of his disciples, and the disciple having the duty of upholding the mentor's vision, seeking to fulfil the unrealised potential of both mentor and student. Most importantly, the Soka Gakkai are organised in a single hierarchical organisation led by a President. They are organised by the principle of "peace, culture, and education", seeking to spread far their message through shakubuku - the practise of proselytisation. It is thanks to their proselytising that the Soka Gakkai managed a miraculous recovery from the Event, their hierarchy and message surviving the fires of the deluge, reaching the hearts of the wayward masses of the American West Coast.

If one thing for sure survived the Event, it is the human desire for wealth. In the gilded casino cities of the West Coast, notorious for their vice and sin, people pray to only one thing - Luck. The goddess Fortuna, Lady Luck herself, is believed to be in control of every single aspect of life. From the gambling games played well into the post-Event era, to the very course of one's life, Luck is the one sole constant of the universe. Thus, to Fortuna's worshippers, gambling has become sort of a religious ritual, meant to measure how favoured one is with the goddess. Whether one is virtuous or sinful has little to no basis on their standing in the faith, for such things have no effect on their Luck. Rulers are expected to gamble constantly, and a ruler who loses all their games is soon to lose all their followers as well, since nobody is willing to go down with the ship except its captain. That being said, Lady Luck is notoriously fickle, and anything can happen - somebody who loses all their money one day may gain it tenfold the next.

Aquarians began as a diverse collection of different groups united by some beliefs and practices, such as karma, channeling, and self-spirituality. These fractured New Age sects were finally united under a common banner by the wise Guru Carina, who reformed the movement and declared the beginning of the eponymous Age of Aquarius. This faith believes in a holistic form of divinity known as The Divine, from which all existence emanates. The purest form of The Divine is The Primal Stream, from which the very first being emanated - The Verbum, containing the ideas of all things possible. Then, The Verbum emanates The Anima - the principle of movement and matter. This cosmology also includes hundreds of intermediate divinities, such as gods, angels, demons and other spiritual beings which act as mediators between The Divine and humanity. This system follows a divide between the spiritual and material worlds, and although the latter is imperfect, it is a place full of beauty where souls can attain spiritual maturity and happiness through enlightenment. After bodily death, the soul moves up a level in the afterlife. Impure souls undergo purification before descending again to reincarnate in a new body. While the purest and maturer souls escape the cycle of rebirth and return to The Primal Stream, becoming one with The Divine, some of these souls choose instead to inhabit the spiritual world, becoming Ascended Masters, acting as teachers and guiding others to enlightenment.

The Cineasts believe in an esoteric pantheon of figures called Archetypes. The Archetypes are not people, but rather metaphysical principles, nameless ideals that embody the pinnacle of humanity. Only if the faithful follow the Hero's Journey through the lessons taught by the Haysian Gurus will they be able to avoid getting a rerun, and earn their place in the Hall of Fame. Embodying an archetype is the ultimate goal in every Cineast's life, aiming to walk the Walk of Fame alongside the great antediluvian sages which accomplished the same, becoming great examples for all to follow.

When the Event led to the near-total destruction of West Coast Christianity, it became the duty of California's Oriental Orthodox Churches to uphold the teachings of Jesus and the Bible. The newly-founded Church of Saint Thaddeus, a unification of the Coptic and Armenian Churches of the West Coast, soon elected a new Catholicos-Patriarch, restoring apostolic succession from Saint Thaddeus himself. It became a safe haven for the wayward Catholics and Protestants who had nobody to guide them in these troubling times. Even now, the Thaddean Church recognises the autonomous rites of the Catholics and Protestants, interdenominational cooperation paving the way to rebuild the world anew.

La Iglesia de Nuestra Senora de Guadalupe, known colloquially as the Guadalupan Church is a post-Event Catholic church founded in opposition to the official Catholic Church in Mexico, led by the Mexican Patriarch. After the Event the Archdiocese of Mexico was abolished, with the Patriarchate of Mexico founded in its place. The new Patriarchate soon started enacting controversial measures in order to prevent the Church's collapse, alienating many priests and bishops, who in turn elected their own Archbishop of Mexico to lead them.\nThe Patriarch of Mexico attempts to actively stamp out worship of folk saints, while the Guadalupanos believe the Church and the Archdiocese should have autonomy over canonisation of saints, at least until direct communion with the Pope is re-established. For this, Guadalupanos are denounced by the Patriarch as being idolatrous, as the Guadalupan Church sees nothing inherently wrong with the reverence of local saints, though they tend to be revered more as deities than saints, with intercession commonly being ignored among adherents.

The Diné believe that their ancestors passed through three different worlds before arriving to the current Fourth or Glittering World. It was here on Nahasdzáán, Mother Earth, that all of nature was created by the Diyin Dine'é, the Holy Men. Humanity was created by the Changing Woman, who personifies the harmony of the universe, and her sons slew the monsters threatening the diyinii. The diyinii then taught the humans how to live in harmony with Mother Earth and Father Sky, and even the smallest insect was instrumental in shaping the Diné way of life. These beliefs center around the practise of ceremonial songs, in which their creation narratives are recited by dancers, and divided into two major ways. The first is the Blessing Way, Hózhóójí, which is used for healing and keeping the balance of the world, and the second is the Enemy Way, Ana'í Ndáá', used to protect from harmful spirits and lay them to rest. Other than that, the Diné have three major chants - the Holy Way for healing and attracting good forces, the Evil Way for exorcising evil and the Life Way for treating injuries.

The Pueblo believe they live in the Taalawsohu, also known as the Fifth World. Pueblo gods are called kachina, existing in three aspects: the supernatural being, the kachina dancers, and kachina dolls. Pueblos believe kachinas are spirits or personifications of things in the real world who have personal relationships both with humans and other kachinas. Not worshiped, kachinas are powerful beings who, if given veneration and respect, can use powers for human good, bringing rainfall, healing, fertility, or protection. Numerous ceremonies and rituals are held throughout the year to honor the kachina, impersonated by male dancers wearing costumes and masks. Their practices are very secretive, and outsiders are not allowed to witness them unless explicitly allowed.

The Native American Church, or Peyotism as called by most, is the syncretic faith of many Native Americans of the old United States. Peyotism was founded long before the Event by the tribes of Oklahoma in order to combine the wise teachings of Christian preachers with the way of life of the native elders. Thus, Peyotism combines Christian morals, influenced by Protestantism, and worship of God and Jesus Christ, with many traditional ceremonies, such as the usage of peyote. The Peyotist god is called the Great Spirit or Great Mystery, and he is ever present in the lives of men, the Holy Spirit inhabiting every crevice and visions being received through the smoking of peyote. The Church has traditionally been divided between two main denominations, or "fireplaces" - the Half Moon fireplace and the Fire Cross fireplace. The Half Moon fireplace rejects many of the more Christian traditions, while the Fire Cross fireplace ceremonies frequently use Bibles, crosses, and Christian religious songs.

After the Event, many Muslims could not believe that such an apocalyptic thing could happen to the world without it being some sort of divine punishment. Some interpreted it as meaning that knoweldge of Islam has become progressively hidden in an age of ignorance, a new jahliyyah, and that this was all divine punishment. Thus when a figure of the name of Salih rose from the rubble of Dearborn claiming to be the infallible Mahdi sent to redeem Islam and unveil what was lost again, many listened. His incredible knoweldge of theology of seemingly all schools of Islam was uncommon in the post-Event age where most were illiterate and didn't have the time for religious practice as they tried to survive the apocalypse, baffling the Muslim community of Minnesota, which rallied under him. His popularity growing, he would establish a caliphate in the region, and spread his revivalist doctrine, which took influences of multiple schools of Islam of the Americas and attracted many of the local tribes. Salih would himself write over one hundred books on religious law during his conquests. Today, his community is still extant, and still uses his works, shortly before his death closing the Ijtihad of Islam, so as to prevent deviation from what he had restored. They regard Salih as infallible, having unveiled what had been lost during the Jahliyyah. They are still waiting to finally take the world out of ignorance. Though the Mahdi himself has died and his ancient conquests are shattered, many Muslims still believe his descendants will finally save the ummah and bring the world out of ignorance eventually.

The ancestral folklore of the various Anishinaabe peoples, such as the Ojibwe, Algonquin, Odawa, Potawatomi, Oji-Cree and various Métis groups, revolves around Gitche Manitou, the "Great Spirit" or "Great Mystery", a supreme deity that is the creator of all that is and the giver of all life. Equally worthy of worship are the manidoog, the spirits that surround us in every day life, and in some communities Mother Earth herself, considered Gitche Manitou's greatest creation. Anishinaabe worship generally takes place inside a variety of secretive Medicine Societies, the most important of which being the Midewiwin, or the Grand Medicine Society. The traditions and rituals of these societies are very closely guarded, and outsiders and not permitted to participate or observe without special privileges, although many of their sacred oral retellings, called adizookanag in Ojibwe, are well recorded and written down.

Before the event the Quakers, also known as the Friends, were most well known for their position as conscientious objectors to war and a mostly silent and leaderless style of worship practiced by a portion, along with a theology focused on a direct and internal relationship with God. While this position has made rulership seem unobtainable in the post event world, a surprising number of Quakers have found a penchant among those working for the merchant class.

Gaihwi:io, or Good Message, is the religion of the Haudenosaunee founded by the Prophet Gä-neo-di-yo. Gä-neo-di-yo was once an unremarkable Seneca noble, whose life was ruined by the Honio?'on`'s fire water, like many on his reserve. Afflicted with a wasting disease that was aggravated by his drinking habit, he was on the brink of death, before receiving a vision of four messengers and being saved by the Great Spirit. This experience would change him, and he would begin preaching the good word of temperance, the love of family and much more to his nation. He would even be recognised by the President of Columbia as the preacher of a true religion.

The Québécois Catholic Church survived the Event, electing their own Patriarch and taking part in the Council of Patriarchs. This prosperity did not last long, however, with the formation of the Gallicanist Papacy. and the total destruction of the position of Patriarch of Québec. With a new Patriarch never being elected, the ardent Catholic traditionalists of Canada who rejected the infallibility of the Holy See of Québec were hunted down and converted or outright killed. Nonetheless, the Old Catholics hold out on the outskirts of Gallicanist control, hoping to one day see the heretic Pope thrown out of Québec and the righteous Patriarchate reestablished.

The Seventh-Day Adventist Church is the largest post-Event Adventist Christian church in the Americas. The movement and the Church were founded before the Event in the United States after what is called the "Great Disappointment", a failed prediction of the Second Coming that tested the faith of many. Nonetheless, their belief of the imminent advent of Jesus Christ was not shaken, and the newly-founded Church massively grew over the years, surviving the Event. Official Adventist belief states that the Event was, in fact, not the prophesied Second Coming, but merely a warning sign. Thus, the Seventh-Day Adventist Church holds steadfast in their beliefs, more prepared than ever for the return of their saviour, after which the faithful will be taken to Heaven for a thousand years, and those who were not saved will cease to exist, leaving only the faithful to prosper on a renewed Earth.

Appalachia and Tennessee have long been where music breathed life into hopeless people, and where legendary pre-Event musicians used their songs to spread prosperity and help others. As the former Music Capital of America, the city of Nashville gave birth to the Harmonics, who venerate the King of Graceland as their prophet. They clung to the Biblical passage describing God as "the Word", believing that voice and language was God's oldest and purest form, and that humans were made in God's image because they are able to best articulate his will through speech and song.

To the Emmaeans, the apocalypse started long before any man was born, and will continue long into the future. Emmaeans believe that time is a cycle: just as the old books of Genesis speak of the flood, so does the Event speak of the flood that destroyed the Old World and left humanity to rebuild. The oracles and judges of the Emmaean faith profess a belief that the next apocalypse is to mirror the last, the first resulting in a total rebirth of the world, as predicted by the very same sages of the ancient past. It was during this previous apocalypse that He Cloaked in Blood took it upon himself to save mankind. Many rejected him however, and were left behind, the Almighty Saviour swearing to come back for them in the next apocalypse. The souls of men are destined to be reborn constantly until He Cloaked in Blood saves them from the endless cycle of time. Thus, the Event heralds his next return, and the fulfilling of Revelation, where one's immortal soul may rejoin the Heavenly Host and be reborn to a New Eden, while the faithless are to once again stay behind on a ravaged Earth and await the next Revelation. The Emmaeans now patiently await the return of Him Cloaked in Blood, not beholden to any bishops or academies - the faithful live simple, orderly lives in service of the Almighty Saviour. He will inevitably arrive, as he did many cycles before, and many will reject him, proving mankind's free will can reject paradise even in the end of days. The gifts of His Holy Spirit prove, however, that mankind is not abandoned yet. The mighty river that once flooded the world and killed many is now the same river that gives life and feeds many, and the same winds that drained a man of his blood now give him life. All this is proof of the mercy of Him Cloaked in Blood, who will love humanity endlessly, and try time and time again to show them truth, no matter how many times he is rejected.

Though the churches of the Free Baptist Convention are peaceful, espousing ideals of justice and equality, there are those who believe they are too pacifistic, too passive in the fight for justice. Many who hold these beliefs have begun to call themselves Abolitionists, calling upon all Christian faithful to "fight for what is right". The Abolitionists are heavily influenced by folk figures such as the martyrs John Brown and Nat Turner, and are unified in their endless crusade against all forms of inequality - most notably racial and class, and most frequently by means of incredible violence. Abolitionist doctrine is thus heavily denounced by the mainstream Free Baptist churches, who claim that such a response against the purported evils of the world is equal to stooping down to their level, only serving to continue the cycle of hatred established during mankind's earliest years. The Abolitionists, however, are not willing to budge, and are generally completely unwilling to engage in dialogue with anyone they consider exploitative of the weak and downtrodden, be it entire faiths or kingdoms.

The origin of this irregular faith can be traced to various American interpretations of different oriental faiths as well as indigenous beliefs. Some sages recall ancient texts from a foreign land, which contained wisdom relating to surviving the physical and spiritual obstacles warriors face, which gradually spread over the centuries - ancient principles of eastern spirituality, particular mindfulness, non-attachment, and compassion, the faith weaving them with the ideals of self-reliance, freedom, and respect for nature. Individual followers practice non-attachment as a form of existential freedom, and compassion as a form of brotherhood. Practitioners meditate in the saddle, when practicing martial activities, and attain a clarity of mind and discipline which allows them to continually improve themselves. The core of the Starry Eyed Path offers a spiritual journey through which enlightenment is possible through the display and encouraging of discipline, resilience, and the upholding of the noble, protective warrior ethos its followers champion.\nWhile the faith's followers truly view life itself as a bringer of conflict, they do not crave violence, rather, as a fundamental part of humanity, it is something to be mastered, and is a testament to one's strength in regards to how they approach it. To the Star Riders, the Sky Father is the ultimate patriarch, but otherwise distant: while he may have made man in his own image, a great number of powerful gods and immortals are honored by the followers of the Art of War, with each clan having their own array of notable figures which are worshipped and honoured, as there is no better method to honor the Sky Father than to leave him undisturbed. Today, the martial aptitude of the nomadic clans and cloistered villages which have fostered the Starry Eyed Path are well known throughout the American Midwest, although their tenuous respect for other faiths have caused conflicts they cannot claim to have won.

The world before was a land of horrors, with every king, judge, and merchant tyrannical and cruel, gaining wealth and power by tormenting those who retained their faith in the face of the hardships inflicted upon them. The wickedness of the lords of the Earth caused such great suffering, and God, in his wisdom, punished every nation of man through the means of a great flood, which washed away all the evils that set brothers upon brothers, those who gained power by dividing God's design through vile plots. Upon the high mounds and mountains, the crowds of those who once hungered as slaves and beggars in their own lands, and all others who held faith close to their hearts waited for generations to receive the ancient laws God once granted Noah, forming a final covenant with all mankind, one uniting all men and women once again as equals in the eyes of the Lord.\nThe Postdiluvians maintain that all men alive today are descendants of those deserving of God's mercy, and that all men are once again worthy of receiving his gifts. As they believe all their wayward cousins are righteous, at least compared to those who came before, they remain content worshipping God's wondrous creation and upholding the sacred laws passed down from father to son. However, they remain keen to ensure that no tyrants emerge among the wayward, knowing what has come before and what is worth preserving.\nPostdiluvians traditionally honour God's creations through communal religious ceremonies, in which sacred herbs known to promote gifts of the Holy Spirit are consumed in order to inspire transcendent states, as per the needs of the flock, and communities engage in the construction of elaborate earthwork monuments meant to honour God and provide a space for major ceremonies, often including forms of pageantry. Many cultivate relationships with the land itself, believing that, as God is omnipresent, everything in God's creation is worthy of worship, being a place for all the disfavored people of the Old World to live as though the demonic forces of the back-then never existed, and the wisest among them are often inductees into the mystical arts.

The denizens of the decrepit Steel Belt talk about the Father of Industry and his great Titans crafted from clay and steel, how they were betrayed by the deceitful Mother Goddess who created life as we know it. On the other side of Lake Michigan, however, prevails a different story, in which the Earth Mother, Gaia, created the first bloom of life on a barren planet, and man alongside it, who was given intelligence to enjoy the beauty of the garden around them.\nHowever, they were soon taught by Father Industry the secrets of the Black Gold, the primordial fuel of the Earth, and it was abused to create great steel skeletons and machines of destruction until the rivers around them laid polluted, the forests desecrated, and the spirits of the world went into hiding. Man retreated into his ivory tower, destroying to his heart's desire, until his precious Black Gold completely ran out. Their machines became lifeless, their cities collapsed and became buried under dirt and sand, and the individuality of man was destroyed, with the vast majority perishing, not knowing how to survive in the world they were created in.\nJust as it began, nature ruled the world once again. The faithful of the Mother now swear to live in harmony with the world around them, worshipping Gaia who created them, the sanctity of birth, and the spirits who have since returned to their ancient homes.

The Warriors of Ludd are a sect of Gaianism who, alongside the Earth Mother, worship her greatest warrior, Ludd. According to legend, Ludd was just a lowly worker in the steel-carved cities of industrial Earth, until he was one day approached in person by the Great Mother herself. Gaia told Ludd to take up arms and retake the Earth back into the hands of the righteous, gifting him a sword powerful enough to cut through steel and rust.\nThus, Ludd and his most loyal followers sabotaged all corners of man's world, burning down manufactories, cutting down towers of steel, and inspiring the workers and peasants of the steel cities to revolt against their overlords until the flames burned out. Inspired by these heroic tales, the faithful Luddites of the new era are dedicated to preventing man's hubris from ever tearing down the sacred nature around them, making sure the world never requires another Ludd to save it.

In the desolate wastes of the post-Event world, the Christian faithful held out. Even against the red plague, starvation, war, idolatry and paganism, the faithful of Christ the Martyr held strong in their beliefs and patiently awaited the return of their Lord to bring them up into Heaven and smite the unbelievers. Except their Saviour never came. There was only one explanation, said Reverend Joshua Whitefield - the Saviour of Mankind will not return until God's green Earth is cleansed. Christ Almighty had judged man from afar, and deemed him too sinful, too cynical, and not worthy of his divine grace. The Second Coming is impossible as long as the world is infested with all those who have turned away from God, and have subsequently been abandoned by him.\nThe sick, the poor, the unsightly, and all the unbelievers comprise the wicked eschelons of society that are too sinful to be rewarded by God, and have no place in the Kingdom of God on Earth. So, the Edenite faithful have taken it on themselves to spread the Divine Gospel to all those who live their lives in the Lord's shadow, be it by kindness or by force, for as long as they plague the Earth they will never be able to herald a new Kingdom of god - a New Eden.

To the Emmaeans, the apocalypse started long before any man was born, and will continue long into the future. Emmaeans believe that time is a cycle: just as the old books of Genesis speak of the flood, so does the Event speak of the flood that destroyed the Old World and left humanity to rebuild. The oracles and judges of the Emmaean faith profess a belief that the next apocalypse is to mirror the last, the first resulting in a total rebirth of the world, as predicted by the very same sages of the ancient past. It was during this previous apocalypse that He Cloaked in Blood took it upon himself to save mankind. Many rejected him however, and were left behind, the Almighty Saviour swearing to come back for them in the next apocalypse. The souls of men are destined to be reborn constantly until He Cloaked in Blood saves them from the endless cycle of time. Thus, the Event heralds his next return, and the fulfilling of Revelation, where one's immortal soul may rejoin the Heavenly Host and be reborn to a New Eden, while the faithless are to once again stay behind on a ravaged Earth and await the next Revelation. The Emmaeans now patiently await the return of Him Cloaked in Blood, not beholden to any bishops or academies - the faithful live simple, orderly lives in service of the Almighty Saviour. He will inevitably arrive, as he did many cycles before, and many will reject him, proving mankind's free will can reject paradise even in the end of days. The gifts of His Holy Spirit prove, however, that mankind is not abandoned yet. The mighty river that once flooded the world and killed many is now the same river that gives life and feeds many, and the same winds that drained a man of his blood now give him life. All this is proof of the mercy of Him Cloaked in Blood, who will love humanity endlessly, and try time and time again to show them truth, no matter how many times he is rejected.

The Loyalists maintain that the lands of Canada were once ruled by a pantheon of God-Kings in times long gone. The God-Kings from beyond the waves granted their powers to the Ministerium, an organization of ascended men appointed to rule in their stead. The divine kings and queens ruled over the world for eons until they were struck down by the Arch-Traitor Washington who, empowered by the spirit of Mordred, possessed the loyal subjects of the Empire and led a rebellion which did not end until every God-King's head was in his hands. The rest of the world may have forgotten their oaths, but the loyal knights of Canada have not. Even if their divine creators are no longer here, their chivalric spirit lives on. The Loyalists have revived the ancient Ministries and continue to lord over Canada as eternal regents, their rule free from the corruptions of the Eagle and the Church.

The United Church of Canada is the largest mainline Protestant denomination of post-Event Canada. Formed before the Event as a via media between various Protestant denominations, it stayed in relative obscurity until the Deluge, after which it absorbed many smaller churches with little opposition, thanks to its congregational and open-minded approach.

Originally emerged prior to the event through the Synchronization of the Yoruba beliefs of the African slaves with the Catholicism of the Spaniards, Santeria has experienced a major syncretism with Catholicism after the event having absorbed the Catholic survivors with the collapse of the Catholic Church in Cuba. This religion believes in the existence of a supreme and universal tripartite god from which everything is derived, being its 3 aspects: Olodumaré, the Father, Olorun, the Holy Spirit, and Olofin, the Son. Although Olodumaré created the universe and was frequently involved in the past, today he no longer intervenes directly in the world, leaving his son Olofin in charge with the help of other intermediaries. This is why the followers of this religion tend instead to worship mainly Olofin, their ancestors' spirits (known as Egun) and the saints or ochas. And although there are probably dozens or hundreds of saints, they worship mainly the seven most important ones, the Seven African Potencies, considered by some as facets of the creator God and by others as Olofin's helpers in governing the world.

The Mississippi River has always held special significance to the middle of old America, giving life and wealth to communities on Her waters and the waters of Her tributaries. Because of this, many believe the river to be more than just that, lending it an air of sacredness to peoples of all creeds who live within Her reach. The most popular expression of this belief is the worship of the Sacred Madonna, a goddess who gave life to the world by creating the river and many others like it. Over the years, a pantheon has developed around the Sacred Madonna, including the Heavenly Father who created Earth and the realm of spirit, and the Good Shepherd, Her son who leads the souls of the dead to the afterlife, and a pantheon consisting of many angels who come from old scripture, popular lore, and the beliefs of their neighbors.\nOriginally, the Madonnite faith was localised to parts of old Illinoy, but with the conquests of Ishmael Arthur and the establishment of the Second Mississippi Empire it has since spread far and wide. With the expansion of the faith also came its restructuring, and Ishmael enlisted the help of the priest Joseph to codify the Madonnite beliefs and create a hierarchy for the faith, with Joseph being the first to claim the title of the Oracle of the Sacred Madonna. Despite the newfound hierarchy, the faith much like the old city states that practise it kept much of its independent and divided nature, with the Oracle not having nearly as much authority as the heads of other faiths. Now that the Empire has fractured, the spread of the Madonnite faith has stalled, though if a strong enough prince were to rise up it could very well continue its march along the banks of the holy waters.

The Primordialists of the Floridian wetlands profess a belief in the Divine Lizard. They believe that during the creation of man, the first humans were born into Eden, where they were protected and watched over by magnificent reptiles. These were the chosen creatues of their lord Caidor, the Emperor of the Cosmos. In this primordial garden, mankind was gifted knowledge by his serpentine lords, and given the freedom to do as he pleases. Thus, man chose to sin, the unbearable weight of his sins culminating in the Extinction Event, where both mankind and the scaled guardians were nearly destroyed, with Hell coming down from the skies and merging with Eden, creating the mortal world that we know. As all life is born from the primordial goop of Eden, all life will one day return to it, and thus return to the God that created it. Now, the Primordialist faithful swear to atone for their past sins, sending the unworthy into the mouths of the remaining sentinels, so their sins may be returned to the Lord and rebuilt into a new Eden, a paradise that awaits the faithful.

The world is filled with oppressive, brutal regimes, each a place of harsh laws and worse punishments. The common man and woman live in constant fear of the tyranny employed by the servants of those who wish to call themselves righteous, or who uphold the values of kings and priests from far-off lands for the sake of extracting all they can gain from the enslaved. There are many who would rejoice if these empires were to be replaced with a more benevolent government, though such a thing may seem fantastical to those who suffer under the whip and lash. There exist whispers of a Golden Age of Piracy, in which absolute freedom from all forms of tyranny once existed, solely due to the actions of esteemed men and women which the world deigned to call Pirates. The promised land these Pirates reigned over was Libertalia, a golden kingdom in which all men were free to do as they wished unfettered, defended by the most cunning and brave among the Pirates themselves.\nThe Golden Age has long since ended, Libertalia becoming a legend, but the Libertalians have yet to cease in their struggle for liberty and self-determinism for all who choose to pursue it against a hostile world. The Libertalian faithful promote personal freedom in all respects, and are keen to break all those shackles which tie good folk to unjust rulers. Those who die with honor are said to go to the Fiddlers Green, where old sailors are made young again, the merriment never ceases, and all men live like kings.

The Rapturist Convention is an organisation of Evangelical churches following Scientologist religious doctrine. They believe that God brought the ancient humans to Earth from space 75 million years ago, at which point he called a great flood. Almost all the ancient humans perished in the flood as punishment for their sin, except for the few that were saved by Noah and his ark. From there, humanity repopulated, but the souls of all the people who died in the flood lingered on in the material world, not being pure enough to ascend to Heaven. These souls affect the souls of all living men, and it is now up to the faithful alive today to atone for millions of years of sin, so they may be able to ascend to Heaven when Jesus returns at the Fountain of Youth in his divine spacecraft.

Calling themselves "yehudim", the Israelites practice a religion that they describe as "messianic Judaism". They consider themselves to be Jews that believe in Jesus Christ as the prophesied Messiah and the Son of God. They consider the entire Bible to be sacred, and they also claim to be Children of Israel, God's chosen people. The Israelites also believe that God is a trinity, consisting of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit. As well as Christian beliefs, they also affirm the Shema, use Hebrew as a liturgical language, and hold that the Torah and Tanakh are fully divine as well as the Bible, though acceptance of the Talmud and Jewish Oral law varies. These controversial positions put them inbetween Christianity and Judaism, representing both but not being claimed by either, though the Israelites are steadfast in their beliefs.

While the influence of charisms has been widely accepted in the greater Protestant world, there are those who believe charismatic gifts have been all but lost in the world created by the Event. Calling themselves "Televangelicals", these groups believe that charisms could be channelled through a holy device dubbed the "teevee", by which the Holy Spirit's divine gifts may be given to all faithful believers. However, mankind grew too greedy, each man channelling the teevee for hours every day, using the gift of God's love for his own selfish indulgences. Thus, the Lord's heavenly energy stopped flowing, and mankind was struck down for its avarice. Now, the Televangelical priests gather and pray in front of the teevees, hoping they may earn God's forgiveness and be given the gift of the Holy Spirit once again.

The Delvers of the Deep Magicks are a wide network of occultist lodges and orders dedicated to one common goal - the uncovering of the Old Lore. Delvers believe that long ago, long before the current age was an Age of Magick, in which men coexisted with elves and dwarves, battled almighty dragons, and received guidance and leadership from their divines. However, the hubris of man transcends time and space, and even the humans of old fought and killed each other and sought extermination over the pettiest of reasons.\nThe hammer came crashing down when the wars turned to world wars, disturbing the core balance of the universe and setting free the Gods of Chaos - ancient lords who seek total anarchy and breakdown of order. This attracted the attention of Ao, the Overgod, the Master of the Universe, who forever divided the world of man and the world of magick. And so, man was left alone in this New World, devoid of spells, and no longer led by their gods.\nNow, the Delvers are those dedicated to harnessing the magick left in our world, hoping to become powerful enough wizards and witches in order to tap into the Other World, and herald the return of Sigmar, the Son of God and Emperor of Man, who will reunite the two worlds once more.

The Community of Christ, or the Reorganised Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints is a Mormon church that traces its roots back to the leadership of Joseph Smith's eldest son Joseph Smith III. While the fellow LDS faithful moved to what is now Deseret under the leadership of President Young, the Community of Christ stayed in the Midwest, where it reorganised itself. Adapting much more theologically liberal beliefs that align with contemporary mainline Protestant thought, the Community became the main source of shelter, charity, and most importantly, hope for the downtrodden of post-Event America. Slowly, but surely, the Community rebuilds old America, brick by brick, in worship of the Heavenly Father.
