At the dawn of time, when there was little in the world but mist and stone, there were giants who dwelt upon the Earth, who shaped the formless world with their cunning magics and sheer strength. As they whittled themselves to a mere scant few, those who survived this primordial conflict allotted to form great clans, and to eventually reap the harvest that they had sown, that being the nascent civilisations of Mankind. 
These giants, the Gibborim, made themselves kings over Man, and they fathered sons and daughters: with time, the Gibborim left the mortal coil in search of a purpose or killed each other in search of power, leaving only their strongest children to reign over the world. Although these giants were few and lesser than their forefathers, their incredible power and personal magnetism made it a simple matter for them to lead Mankind towards a glorious Golden Age, where the god-kings of the world lived among mortals.
The Golden Age was doomed to fail, due to new and cowardly spirits. These spirits were cowards and tempted the weak Men who lacked the hearty, vigorous blood that pulsed through the veins of the giant-kin to worship them and subvert the great kingdoms of yore. Alas, the great dynasties fell one by one, until soon all Men worshipped gods that they could see only in their dreams, rather than at the helm of great nations. Those who still claim faint descent from the Gibborim have since reclaimed the name of their ancestors after the end of time, having reconstructed their collective identity as the heirs to the world-rulers in a time where the Gibborim hold more worldly power than they have had in thousands of years, no more regulated to old stories of trolls and ogres haunting the hills, or as hairy beasts scorned by the followers of the so-called true gods.
Everything in Gibborim culture is based on bloodlines, as the inherent strength and spiritual capabilities of a Gibborim is directly proportional to how far removed he is perceived to be from one of the old dynasties, and anyone who would dare call themselves a Gibborim lord knows their entire lineage back to the comely mortals that their titanic ancestors engaged with. While all the old bloodlines are heavily diluted. The Gibborim, meanwhile, consider the right to consume human flesh as their birthright, as mankind is both provender and family to the great ones: the god-kings once slacked their thirsts in grand ceremonies, but the Gibborim now are content to consume the flesh of lesser men to ensure that their divine nature is obvious to all, as they are above all laws which stem from the teachings of ephemeral gods.

The Shangavasampradaya tradition of Caribbean Hinduism only formed after the Event shook the islands to their core. Shangavists worship Shango, the Yoruba god of thunder, as Para Brahman, the Supreme Being. Shangavist tradition states that Shiva was the original conception of Olodumaré, the Ultimate Reality, until he one day rebirthed himself as a mortal named Shango, becoming the King of Oyo, and ascending to divinity upon death. Now, Shango is worshipped as both the creator and the destroyer, and the source of all minor gods and orishas. He is authoritative and wrathful, being the god of destruction, but also the creator of all love and life, and his followers believe that a life in service of Shango will lead them to escape the cycle of rebirth and be reunited with their god.

The Hare Krishna movement traces its originis back to the Old World, in the far away land of Bharat. The bhaktas, as they call themselves, are devout followers of the god Krishna, the azure-skinned Hindu god of love and compassion. Krishna is worshipped as Svayam Bhagavan, the Supreme Being, and is cherished as the ultimate creator. They teach that Krishna is the source of all other gods and avatars, including the Trimurti, Jesus, and Lady Columbia. To them, Krishna is God, and the bhaktas worship him in magnanimous festivals filled with all forms of singing, dancing, and chanting.\nThe only exception is their dual worship of Radha, Krishna's faithful wife. While Krishna represents all the masculine aspects of the universe, Radha represents all the feminine, and together they form the cosmic balance between the male and female realities of the world. The bhaktas believe that reality is ultimately an illusion, and a pious person will return to the source of all energy - brahman - upon escaping the cycle of death and rebirth. Though very far away from their homeland, they are still devoted to preaching and spreading the love of Krishna wherever they go, backed by an extensive organisation of priests and gurus.

The indigenous peoples of central Mexico have been firmly Catholic for centuries before the Event, even if the influence of their old gods and ancestral folklore never really went away. Many traditions have died out since then, new ones taking their place, creating a faith that attempts to explain Christian beliefs through myths as old as the religion itself. The most important divinity is Our Precious Mother, Tonantzin, who is the Blessed Virgin of Guadalupe, and the mother of God and all Mexicans. God Himself consists of a duality, one side being the Father, Tloque nahaque, who is the Lifegiver and the creator of the world, and the other being the Son, Quixto, whose prophesied coming signals the end of the current cycle and the coming of the next. Together they form the One God, Icelteotl, who is simultaneously he who creates and he who destroys the world, and his temper is only controlled by the love and care of the mother Tonantzin.\nMan's destiny is decided at birth by a battle between Icelteotl and the Devil, Tlacatecolotl. The victor determines whether the child receives a good shadow, becoming destined to succeed in life and ascend to Heaven, or a heavy shadow, being destined to sinning and going to Hell. Men who die in battle and women who die in childbirth go directly to Heaven regardless, while the souls of those who drowned go to an earthly paradise inhabited by the Rain Dwarfs. The Quixtianos believe in three heavens: a flower garden for children, a heaven for adults, and a kingdom for God and his Saints. The Saints have become much resembling minor deities on their own, who lose their temper, take revenge and strike deals with mortals, their images being dressed and worshiped as divine personages. Hell, called Mictlan, is ruled by demons called "pingos", who burn wood under the damned souls and sting them with pitchforks. Only those accused of murder and nahualism are condemned to it.

The Jehovah's Witnesses are those who believe themselves to be the ones meant to bring witness of Jehovah to the people of the Earth. They believe they are the ones who know the truth of the Bible and the will of God, as well as deep uncovered knowledge of the future, hidden among the pages of the Holy Scriptures. They believe that soon, the status quo of the world will be uprooted and destroyed by the return of Archangel Michael, the heavenly form of Jesus Christ, who is the son of God. With his Host of 144,000 kings in Heaven, he will wage the final world war called Armageddon, delivered by God, which the Witnesses see as a rescue operation for Jehovah's people. The true believers will then be given the Earth to live on it for eternity, as Death will be no more.

It is known among many that Cain slew his brother Abel. However, few would identify all of humanity as the descendants of Cain. The Marked do exactly that, and consider all remaining men who survived the Event to be those who were damned by the laws written before the creation of man. Those who believe themselves to carry the Mark of Cain understand that they are doomed to an eternity of pain at the hands of devils regardless of their actions. Those among the Marked adhere to the belief that they are, in essence, damned from the moment they are born, as God's elect have all perished and only the dredges of mankind remain, those designated to be tormented, providing a model to define themselves against for those with the true capacity to repent for their sins.\nThe only true succor the Marked hold dear regarding the futility of their existence lies in the core of their theology: while Heaven is barred from them and spreading the gospel is futile, as no grace will ever be given to the damned, a wholly pure and simple life, one dedicated to repenting for the sins of existence all men commit, may allow for a soul to be annihilated upon death, or are at least allowed to 'sleep', rather than be tormented for all eternity. Accordingly, the Marked partake in numerous ritual practices to separate themselves from and appease the evil spirits of the world, while maintaining what little spiritual purity their impure existences can maintain, all for the possibility that they may avoid eternal damnation through destroying all which may fetter them to the demonic forces tied deeply to the physical world, and pray fervently that God pays little heed to those imperfections they themselves have which damned all of their forefathers.

The Watchers in the Dark are a Catholic religious organisation founded by refugees who fled the Windland floods. Arriving east in the land of Ohio, their preaching very quickly turned to total war, as they were met with fierce raiders from across the Ohio river. With the Event in full swing, Christianity in Canada found itself in crisis. From the first days of the end, the priests and bishops of the Atlantic coast knew the faith is collapsing, with many losing faith in the Lord and many more finding new faith in pagan chants and heathenism. Nonetheless, as the well preserved Archives of Halifax bear witness, the Year 2084 marks the first Council of Halifax, in which the most esteemed priests of the Catholic Church of Canada, the United Church of Canada, and the Anglican Church of Canada looked past their petty ecclesiastical differences.
The final decision of the Council was a huge tide of change. The three churches would establish full communion, contrary to the classic definition of the term, and completely reform the governance of Christianity in Canada, permitting local churches to control entire parishes in order to safeguard the faith. Soon, the local bishops would become priest-kings, and the local churches would grow out into parish-monasteries, with monks and nuns forming essential parts of the new administrations.
A new central body was founded in the Council - the Insular Episcopal Order. However, it was not to oversee each bishopric directly, but merely serve as a holy order of monk-warriors to defend the faith from pagan incursions. Now, the Christians of the North Atlantic live relatively peaceful lives, with Catholics and Protestants sitting in the same churches, performing the same rituals, and praying to the same Lord.
What started out as a shaky, desperate relationship united in faith yet further disunited in contradictions soon grew to outlast many who attempted to do the same. However, piracy has always been an issue for the icy waters of the Atlantic, and with spreading rumours of an immortal empire across the seas coming to claim their souls, only time will tell if the new age of monasticism in the Americas will last.
